head_text.subj: A RAUCOUS VOICE, (SWIMMERS)

text: A RANGE OF MOUNTAINS SLOWLY EMERGES: shrouded in a blue m like a Chinese water color. Below them, close to a small  town, YOUNG MEN, armed with vicious sticks and stripped t the waist, come charging in a muscular, steaming pack. Their opponents, also swinging sticks, attach the pack. A ball, barely round, made of leather, emerges, smacked  forwards by INMAN, who hurtles after it and collides with stick swung by SWIMMER, a young and lithe American Indian Inman falls, clutching his nose. The ball bobbles on the  ground in front of him. He grabs it and gets to his feet, the blood pouring from his nose. His team form a phalanx around him and he continues to ch A PRISTINE CABRIOLET pulled by an impressive horse, comes down towards the town. It has to pass across the temporar field of play, parting the teams. Some of the contestants grab their shirts to restore propriety as the Cabriolet a its two exotic passengers passes by. The driver is a man in his early fifties, dressed in the  severe garb of a minister, MONROE. And next to him, a sel conscious girl in the spotless elaborate, architectural s of the period, is his daughter, ADA. Inman, using his shi to staunch his battered nose, looks at Ada, astonished by her. An angel in this wild place. Now Swimmer stops chanting and begins, more hesitantly, t translate into English:

You will be lonely. You will howl  like a dog as you walk alone. You  will carry dog shit cupped in your  hands. You will be smeared with dog  shit. Your spirit will wane and  dwindle to blue, the colour of  despair...
As the Cabriolet passes, SWIMMER takes the ball an with a whoop starts to run towards the opposing goal. The game  resumes. Ada looks back as the men swarm into each other, sticks and fists flailing.

head_text.subj: EXT. COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. NIGHT

text: A SIDE OF BEEF turns on a huge barbecue. The battered tea eating, drinking hard liquor, rehearsing victory and defe illuminated by a roaring bonfire. Swimmer is sewing up a  gash in Inmans cheek as he continues to translate:
...This is your path. There is no  other. That's a curse you can use on  the Yankee before battle.
And that works?
You have to say it in Cherokee.
You said it to me in Cherokee.

During this, Monroe and Ada have arrived, escorted by SAL SWANGER, a local woman, middle-aged, kindly, and her husb ESCO, a glorious curmudgeon. The Monroes are introduced t various locals. Inamn watches them, on the other side of crowd. The Reverend Monroe, his daughter Ada. Up from  Charleston, bringing God's word to you heathens! Is Esco' preferred introduction. Building a church. Inman watches  Ada, moves his head to keep her in view as Swimmer stitch and winces with pain.
So keep your head still.
Sally collects plates for the Monroes. Hands them to Ada her father, who wait, patiently, for silverware. Esco tak a plate, picks up a skewer of meat, bites on it. Monroe  pluckily follows suit.
(to Swimmer) Anyway, there won't be any war. And  if there is, they say it won't last  a week.

YEAR OF THE CIVIL WAR.

text: A STAND OF TREES. The pastoral lush green Virginia. A RAB surfaces from its hole. Peace and beauty. A second RABBIT shakes itself from the ground, darts into open ground to confront the FORBIDDING TRENCHES OF THE

head_text.subj: CONFEDERATE AND UNION ARMIES, RANGED AGAINST EACH OTHER O

text: THE OUTSKIRTS OF PETERSBURG. Massive wooden barricades in the shape of crosses, rows of X's, define the two lines. Federals have been laying siege for months. So early and  it's already hot. The trees are an oasis of green in a wo of mud between the two stark and ugly scars of the trench IN THE CONFEDERATE LINES, the men are rousing, boiling wa for coffee or to shave, smoking, stiff from night. There' large gun emplacement and some men still sleep against th stub-nosed cannon. Another RABBIT is disturbed from its h Ears pricked up to a distant rumbling. INT. TUNNEL. PREDAWN. A dark hole. Some evil place. A scraping sound. Shapes  burrowing forwards at a crouch. A silent purpose. EXT. CONFEDERATE LINES. PREDAWN. Young OAKLEY, freshly recruited, approaches a group of me like him Highlanders from Company F of the 25th North Car Regiment. He doles out breakfast. Inman, loading his heav LeMats pistol, its nine rounds, is not hungry. Oakley ser another, ROURKE, last seen in the scrum at Cold Mountain. Oakley keeps his head low as he serves.
Don't worry, son. Those Yankee boys  keep store hours. They ain't open  yet.

Shadows and shapes. A BARREL rumbles along the tunnel. It reaches a kneeling figure, who rolls it forwards. A relay team. At the end of the tunnel, where it widens, a man, n to the waist, crouches, stacking the barrels.
A RABBIT, scared up, darts along the trench. Rourke sees beckons to another Cold Mountain boy, Butcher.
That's fresh breakfast. Shoot him!
I'm not firing, start the damn war  off.
Butcher chases after the rabbit, Rourke in raucous suppor
The crouching man has wrapped FUZE WIRE around the last  barrel, and now retreats, paying out the wire as he does as each man in the tunnel crawls backwards behind him.

head_text.subj: EXT. CONFEDERATE LINES. DAWN

text: Rourke weaves through the gun emplacements, laughing.
That's my rabbit!
Great sport. Inman, fifty yards away, looks over, amused, goes back to his gun.

head_text.subj: INT. TUNNEL. DAWN

text: The fuze wire is lit. It fizzes towards the barrels.

head_text.subj: EXT. CONFEDERATE LINES. DAWN

text: Rourke is running BUT NOW THE GROUND BUCKLES UNDER HIM AN HE'S BEING LIFTED SLOWLY INTO THE AIR, the earth swelling

head_text.subj: AN APOCALYPTIC EXPLOSION. FOUR TONS OF DYNAMITE RIP THE G
OPEN IN A CRATER 135 FEET LONG, 90 FEET ACROSS, 30 FEET D
HORSES, GUNS, MEN ARE BLOWN TO PIECES AND THROWN UP INTO
AIR.
INMAN DISAPPEARS UNDER DIRT AND DEBRIS.

text: Pandemonium. The Confederates are in complete disarray. T Federals pour forwards across NO MANS LAND, through the  peaceful oasis of trees, roaring the roar of attack. They flood towards the crater, hundreds of them, charging into dense and impenetrable WALL OF SMOKE.

head_text.subj: THEN THEY'RE INSIDE THE GREAT GASH OF CRATER AND CAN'T GE

text: OUT AGAIN, arriving at an insurmountable wall of mud. The Confederates regroup. Orders are yelled. Chaos develo into battle. The Confederates begin firing into the crater. Guns and m wheel round and empty into what is becoming a terrible de trap. Inman gets to his feet. Oakley with him, and rushes throu the smoke to the pit, emptying his LeMats into the crater LATER: A BLACK REGIMENT from the Union join the attack. B falling on bodies as the Federals charge in and pack thei comrades even tighter. The Confederates make a pincer mov outside the Crater, forcing all the Federals in. It's  Medieval. No escape. THE CONFEDERATES jump into the pit to engage the Federals Hand to hand fighting. Too close for rifles, just bayonet and guns swung like clubs and Inman sliding down into tha hell, tiring the nine rounds, then the shotgun charge, wh does a terrible damage. Primitive. Unutterable carnage. M killing each other in embraces, soldier crushed against  soldier, desperate to survive, to kill, to live. An oozin layer cake of bodies, dead and frantically alive, drownin in slick. YOUNG OAKLEY loses his rifle and picks up a magazine case clubbing his opponent, then slips onto him and is stuck w a bayonet, the pain of which makes him squeal. INMAN GOES AT IT. He's a warrior, punching and stabbing a firing. A coldly efficient killer. He's grabbed from behi and crushed, a hand gouging at his face, an almighty stru He falls and lands on top of Oakley, and he and his Feder opponent fight to the death with the wounded boy as their pillow. The slaughter continues over and around them, the sound, the sound of hell and madness. The boy has his arm around Inman, like lovers. LATER: The Confederates run after the retreating Union  soldiers, firing, cavalry riding them down. Inman stands, the boy's blood all over him, exhausted and appalled. The crater, behind him, an abattoir of men. The victors are  yelling, pumped mad with adrenaline. Butcher comes alongs Inman.
That was something! That's hell and  we've been there! Kicked old Nick's  asshole.

A WOUNDED BLACK SOLDIER sits up as Butcher celebrates. Butcher runs over, but can't find a charge for his musket He looks around in the stack of corpses, pulling out weap tries one: not loaded, throws it down, tries another: not loaded. The wounded man can't get up, tries to drag himse like a crab away from Butcher. Inman yells at him, appall
You got a charge?
He picks up another musket. It fires. The wounded Federal slumps back, dead.

head_text.subj: EXT. CONFEDERATE LINES. DUSK

text: THE AFTERMATH. The dead being piled up for burial, divide into allegiance. Wounded prisoners able to walk are led a A great deal of casual looting. Of boots, of equipment, o personal items. Inman sees a soldier in the crater, linin up wounded Federals, putting their heads in a row. THE MA

head_text.subj: EXTRACTS A HAMMER FROM HIS BELT AND, SATISFIED HE HAS AN
ECONOMIC ARRANGEMENT, PROCEEDS DOWN THE LINE, SMASHING EA
SKULL.

text: Inman turns away, sees another Rebel, extravagantly costu a strange FIDDLE head protruding from his knapsack. This STOBROD THEWES. He's bent over a dead Federal, examining mouth. He reaches behind his back and roots around in the knapsack, producing A PAIR OF PLIERS, WHICH HE INSERTS IN THE CORPSE'S MOUTH. He's yanking away when A SWINGING BOO connects with his head and knocks him to the ground. Startled, he looks up to see Inman hovering over him.
That's gold in his mouth he got no  need for. (shrugs) We take his boots.

He examines his fiddle for damage. Some orderlies pass,  lifting OAKLEY away on a gurney. Oakley's pale as a maiden, the life leaking from him. Inm walks a way with him. Oakley looks up, desperate to be br
I got a few. You saw?
I saw.
I know you don't recognise me. I'm  Mo Oakley's boy. (Inman finds this  incredible) It's okay. I was thirteen when you  all left. Am I going to die?
Inman flicks his eyes to the Orderly, whose look confirms the boy's wounds are certainly mortal.

head_text.subj: INT. FIELD HOSPITAL. NIGHT

text: Inman sits on the ground beside Oakley's cot. Around them the wounded are certainly dying, makeshift care, oil ligh groans.
I'd like to hear some music while I  go.

head_text.subj: EXT. CONFEDERATE LINES. NIGHT

text: Inman walks around the campfires. He hears some fiddle mu It's Stobrod. Stobrod sees Inman. Inman stares, his expression an  instruction, the turns and walks away.

head_text.subj: INT. FIELD HOSPITAL. NIGHT

text: Stobrod stands over Oakley. Consults with Inman.
What about Bonaparte's Retreat? That's  one I play.
Play me something sweet. Like a girl's  waiting for me.
Stobrod looks at Inman, confused.
Play me something like there's nothing  to fear from a merciful Lord.
(to Stobrod) You heard him.
(nervous) I only know a couple of tunes.
Like when you're thirsty up at  Bishop's Creek and the water is so  cool.

Inman glares at Stobrod. And Stobrod starts to play. Hesitant, then with gathering confidence, improvising,  increasingly expansive, as if he's as surprised as everyo else. Oakley's lips move. A whisper. Inman leans in.
I'm reaching Cold Mountain before  you.
Stobrod plays. It's wrenching. Oakley stills. Inman abrup puts his hand on the neck of the fiddle, stopping Stobrod The boy is dead. Inman gets to his feet and walks away.

head_text.subj: INT. CONFEDERATE TENT. NIGHT

text: A dozen men in the tent. Inman has a BOOK, its cover gone rolled up and tied with a leather strap. His bookmark is FADED TINTYPE PHOTOGRAPH of a solemn young woman. He unwr the book carefully and reads a page by the sickly light n to his bedroll. An OFFICER comes into the tent, approache Inman, who makes a stand.
Don't get up, soldier. You are  mentioned tonight in my report. You  are a credit to the Highlands, to  North Carolina and to the Cause.
(tight) Do you have news, sir, on my  application for transfer?
I know. A bloody day. It's what our  General said: Good thing war is so  terrible else a man might end up  liking it too much.
Sir. It was my understanding the  medical corps was desperate for  volunteers.
Right now, soldier, it's me who is  in need of volunteers. There's a  dozen Yankees in that stand of trees  between us. Stuck there from the  retreat. Come daylight they can shoot  us down for sport.

head_text.subj: EXT. CONFEDERATE LINES. NIGHT

text: A beautiful night. Lots of stars. Inman and three others, including Butcher, slide over the top of the trench, far one side of the stand of trees. The plan is to cast a wid arc that will bring them around back of the trees, closer the enemy side than their own. The four men slither over ground. They pause. Inman has arrived at a tangle of corp He slithers over them. They work their way towards the trees. THERE ARE A HALF D FEDERALS CROUCHING IN THE COVER OF THE TREES. They are do Only one of them sits with a rifle surveying the Confeder lines, the others have their backs to the enemy, sitting  against the trunks, grabbing a few minute's sleep. As the four rebels approach, still crawling, one of the  Federals opens his eyes, sees the attack, shifts for his  rifle. INMAN IMMEDIATELY STANDS UP, FIRING INSTANTLY, kil him and two others, while Butcher throws himself at anoth The exchanges are brief and savage and one of Inman's par and all of the Federals lay dead. Then the rebels break f the trees. A FLARE goes up, then another, both from the Confederate  trenches. INMAN AND HIS ACCOMPLICES ARE PICKED OUT IN A  BRILLIANT GREEN LIGHT. Shots follow, from both sides, aim at the three returning men as they zigzag towards their o lines. As they get close, voices cry out, rippling down t trench, joining their own admonitions: Don't shoot, Hold  your fire, they're our boys, Hold your fire!!! They're al home. Butcher is laughing, whooping. Then just as suddenl he falls, wounded. Inman stops, turns back, runs to him. Inman collects Butcher, drags him, carries him. They're f yards from their lines. A BULLET CATCHES INMAN IN THE NEC He goes down like a tree, blood pouring from his neck. Ly on the ground, he watches the phosphorescent lights slowl fade to black, all sound fading with them.

head_text.subj: EXT. CHAPEL, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. 3 YEARS EARLIER. DAY

text: A WOODEN JOIST swings across the view of the Blue Ridge. are swarming over the roof of an unfinished CHAPEL, below which appears the small town of COLD MOUNTAIN. Among the  workers, armed with nails and hammer, knees clutching a  rafter, is Inman, fresh and a whole lifetime younger. Rou and Butcher are also there hammering, building, kidding a and Oakley, barely a teenager. Below them, women are setting up a lunch for the workers, ADA amongst them. She has the circumspect air of the blue stocking, uncomfortably aware of the dirt beneath her hem the men's radar for her every move. Inman watches her as  Sally Swanger approaches.
(to Ada, as Monroe  moves off) Ada, how are you settling in? Are  you liking the farm?
Very much. It's beautiful country.
So listen -- if you would say hello  to one of these fools, I'll get a  field cleared this weekend.
Anyone? Like a forfeit?
(pointing at Inman  who immediately looks  away) No. Him in particular, up in the  rafters. Been pressing me all morning.
UP ON THE ROOFBEAMS OF THE CHAPEL, the men are preoccupie with talk of secession from the Union.
(hammering) I call this nail: Northern Aggression. (hammering) I call this nail: a free nigger.
Show some respect -- these nails are  making a church.
(hammering) I call this nail: respect the church.
Ada comes over, carrying a tray of lemonade glasses. Call up to Inman.
Hello.
Inman swings down. He feels the other men staring, burnin hole in his head.
I'm Ada Monroe.
I'm Inman.
Inman?
W. P. Inman.
W. P. Inman.
Repeating a thing doesn't improve  it. (shrugs) People call me Inman.
If you were to take a glass of  lemonade your friends might stop  staring. Inman.
They're not my friends.
He drops down to ground level, takes the lemonade, scowls the other guys. They're breaking for lunch and as they ma their way to the trestle tables -- they enjoy jostling In
Thank you.
And what do you do?
I work wood. Got a piece of land.  Mostly work wood.
Clear fields?
(uncomfortable) I can clear a field.
So, was there something in particular  you wished to say to me?
(thinks about it) Not that comes to me. (hands back the glass) I'll say thank you for the lemonade.
And he turns and joins the other men gathering round the  tables for lunch. Ada watches him, intrigued. Rourke and approach ESCO SWANGER, a known sympathizer with the North to give him a bad time.
Esco loves the Yankees.
I prefer a Yankee to a halfwit.
Inman arrives just as Rourke points a warning finger at E He pushes the finger down to get by. Esco continues:
What is it you think you'd be fighting  for?
The South.
And what's that when it's at home?
Esco's sons, ELLIS AND ACTON, who're working at the other end of the building, have now arrived at the table.
Pop, you causing trouble?
No.
That means yes.
You cut the wood, you carry the water  for good old King Cotton. Now you  want to fight for him. Somebody has  to explain it to me.
(to Rourke and the  others) Don't even try.
The others are desperate to tease Inman.
How's the lemonade? Sweet?
Ada, at the lemonade stand again, watches them laughing a Inman, who keeps his head fixed on the table.

head_text.subj: EXT. CONFEDERATE LINES. NIGHT

text: INMAN, ON A GURNEY, carried, someone with a cloth to his  neck, which is soaked through with blood. They start to r with him, heading for the field hospital, worried that he will die before the wound can be staunched, cauterized. Throughout, A STRANGE MUSIC PLAYS, discordant notes jangl

head_text.subj: EXT. SWANGER FARM. COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY

text: -- from A PIANO, lashed to a cart, as it bounces along th lane, passing the Swanger Farm. Sally comes out to look.  It's Ada riding next to one of the farmhands, a second bo keeping watch over the piano. Sally goes over.
That's a fine looking thing.
I've been missing it.
Thank you, by the way. (from Ada's quizzical  look) Inman's down in the bottom field,  clearing his debt.
Oh dear. And then he had nothing to  say.
He was happy.
Really?
Are men so different in Charleston?

Men? I don't know. I don't even know  what a woman should be like. In  Charleston I was called a thistle,  twice, by two different men. Both of  them -- they were hunting for a  simile, what was I like -- and thistle  came right to them.
If you're saying you might like him,  why not go down and say hello.

head_text.subj: EXT. BOTTOM FIELD, SWANGER FARM. DAY

text: Inman's working in the field, stripped to his undershirt, hot work, wielding a scythe. He hears something and looks at the edge of the lane, ADA IS PLAYING THE PIANO, which still strapped to the cart. She briefly raises a hand to  Inman, then nods to the farmhand who sets them on their w again. Inman smiles, waves back, watching as the cart rum off down the track.

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT

text: It's pouting with rain. INSIDE THE FARMHOUSE, ADA IS PLAY THE PIANO. Men and women crowd into the parlour, in best clothes,  celebrating the completion of the Chapel. Inman is outsid on the porch, his coat soaked, water pouring off his hat. looks at Ada. She finishes. Monroe steps in front of the  applause, smiling. His words of thanks leak through the w to Inman, who stands, watching, listening.

head_text.subj: INT. PARLOUR, BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT

text: Monroe circulates, with Ada. He nods at a group of men, w congregate in one part, not mingling. Their leader, TEAGU might be a minister himself, favouring a black dress coat black crow in the corner, eyes flashing. Ada doesn't know them. Esco comes by. Monroe puts a hand on his arm.
Esco, our friends there -- (indicating Teague  and co.) -- they helped build the Chapel?

That's Teague and his boys. I'd  recommend you kick them out except a  man don't kick a snake. One time the  Teague family owned the whole of  Cold Mountain. My farm, your farm,  all belonged to his grand-daddy.  Teague wanted this place bad. You  got it. He's here sniffing out an  advantage.
There's no advantage here, but to  celebrate a job well done. Cheers -- (he raises his glass) -- and thank you.
And Teague raises his glass across the room.

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT

text: Ada appears at the door opening it onto the porch. She's  carrying a tray with drinks. Acknowledges Inman.
Were you planning to come inside?
I'm wetter than a fish.
There's a good fire going.
I'm all right.
Somebody said you were enlisting. (no response) Are you?
If there's a war we'll all fight.
(unimpressed) If there's a mountain we'll all climb,  if there's an ocean we'll all drown.
Call a thing a war makes it a  challenge to some men.
Did you get a picture made?
Say again.
A tintype, with your gun and your  courage on display.
You're laughing at me.
I don't know you.
You're always carrying a tray.
I'm taking a drink over to the negroes  in the barn.
(takes the tray) I'll do that. I can't get much wetter.
He goes into the night rain. She watches him.

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: A beautiful day, the farm peaceful. Inman walks up the pa to the farmhouse, its borders flowering and pretty, a sla woman weeding. He knocks on the door. Monroe answers.
Mr. Inman.
Reverend.
What can I do for you?
Inman hovers, awkward. Ada appears, awkward.
I have some sheet music. Belonged to  my father. No use to me.
Ada comes forward, takes the package.
You must come in.
I should probably get along.
Mr. Inman is more comfortable  outdoors. Perhaps we might take a  walk.
A splendid idea.

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Monroe and Inman and Ada touring the farm. It's a biggish property, over three hundred acres. And well-tended by th dozen slave farmhands who work it, some of whom are dotte about in the landscape. Rolling mountains dominate the vi
(expansive) I want to get sheep into this field.  A big field doesn't look right without  sheep. You're a lucky fellow, Mr.  Inman, you've had this view all your  life.
I think so.

It's a special view. I dragged my  poor daughter to Cold Mountain from  Charleston because of my Doctors --  they say my heart is weak -- so the  air's meant to do me good. But it's  the view I think heals.
Ada walking behind, comes alongside the two men, threadin her arm into her father's but, by so doing, also arriving next to Inman.
I have to get on my visits. Can I  offer you a ride back into town?
Inman looks at Ada. No word.

head_text.subj: INT. PARLOUR, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: From the window Ada watches the Cabriolet head towards to At the piano, she unwraps the leather lace from the packa of music. Inside the first book of music, there's a  DAGUERREOTYPE OF INMAN with his LeMats, a typical Confede pose. Some of the music has left its imprint on the pictu the notes like a melody over Inman's face. Ada picks them out on the piano. The ebullient sound of Shape Singing. A noisy choir letti rip --

head_text.subj: INT. CHAPEL, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN, MAY 20TH, 1861. DAY
-- THE WHOLE CHURCH IS SINGING, MEN TO ONE SIDE

text: THE OTHER. Monroe conducts, sings. Inman is there, as is  Ada. He fixes on her neck, the way the hair falls. The door bursts open. Young OAKLEY, apologetic nod to Mon sits at the back, then leans forward, as the singing  continues, to say something to Rourke, who says something Butcher, the news spreading like wildfire. Rourke gets up leaves. Butcher gets up next, follows. Another man. Anoth Depleting the male voices, until only women and some of t older men are singing and one side of the church is  practically empty. Inman, remains, fixed on Ada. Who does not look round.

head_text.subj: EXT. CHAPEL, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY

text: Those left in the congregation now spill out into what ha become a melee as the NEWS OF SECESSION goes up. Enormous excitement, particularly among the boys, who now seem  curiously attractive to the girls. Inman blinks out into sun, Ada finds him. They're awkward as they watch other  sweethearts embracing.
Well, you have your war.
TEAGUE AND HIS MEN COME RIDING UP THE STREET, their horse clearing a path amongst the celebrating crowd. Teague rei in his horse and rides it up against Esco Swanger.
Those who follow Lincoln, or preach  abolition, best keep one eye open  when they're sleeping, Old Bogey Man  might get you!
Inman steps between Esco and Teague, holding the reins of Teague's horse, easy and dangerous.
Are you the law all of a sudden?
Teague produces a document, which he waves in the air.
That's right, son. Home Guard for  Haywood County. I'm the law from  today. You all go fight now. We'll  watch your sweethearts.
And he spurs on his horse, his fellow Home Guard falling behind, riding on over the ridge. Inman walks to Ada.
You might be safer back in Charleston.
But then who'll be waiting for you?
She puts a hand on his arm for a second. They both want t get to the point of declaration but don't know how. They  stand, people noisy around them, those about to leave, th about to be left.
I'm going to walk back inside the  Chapel.
And he does so, making his meaning clear for her to follo

head_text.subj: INT. CHAPEL, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY

text: Inman walks inside. Stands with his back to the door. It  opens and closes. Inman turns. It's Monroe.
Did you want a quiet word?
Now the door opens again and it's Ada. She's dismayed to her father.
Just some quiet.
Of course Ada.
He indicates they should both leave. Inman sits at a benc

head_text.subj: EXT. COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY

text: Monroe and Ada come into town in their cabriolet. They pa under banners proclaiming the Confederate cause: Old Rip' Awake! Watch out Yankees! The trap draws up by the Cold  Mountain General Store. Monroe lets Ada down.
(of his appointment) I'll daresay Dr. O'Brien'll want to  do a test or two.
And then there'll be a coffee or  two, a brandy or two...
Monroe smiles in acknowledgement, gets back in the trap. heads into the store.

head_text.subj: INT. BEDROOM. ROOMING HOUSE. COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY

text: INMAN SITS ON HIS BED, wearing pants and a vest. His room like a monk's cell. Nothing in it. Inman's trunk is packe He's polishing his boots, in his bare feet. One hand insi the boot, the other blacking it. There's a knock at the d He opens it. It's Ada. He abruptly closes the door on her

head_text.subj: INT. HALLWAY, ROOMING HOUSE. COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY

text: Ada waits outside. She's not sure what's happening. Then  Inman opens the door. He's buttoning his shirt. His boots are on, one conspicuously dirty, one highly polished. Som walks up the stairs, carrying a jug and bowl. They separa as the man passes them. They're tender, awkward.
I found you this book. William  Bartram. They tell me it's good. I  think he writes about these parts,  the author, so...
Inman takes it. She has something else. Wrapped in paper.
And this... (hands it to him) I'm not smiling in it. I don't know  how to do that, hold a smile, so now  I'm solemn...
Ada...
What?

HE KISSES HER, pressing into her, his arm circling her wa Below them the sound of a MARCHING BAND. It's the RECRUIT PARADE and brings Rourke and Butcher racing down the stai Inman pulls away from Ada as the boys hurtle for the fron door.
Let's go!

head_text.subj: EXT. COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY

text: Rourke, Butcher, and then Inman appear in the doorway of Rooming House, and then fall in with the motley crew of  Volunteers AS THEY MARCH BY WITH THE BAND AND THE ENLISTE SOLDIERS. The town is out to wish them well, parents, you brothers, sweethearts walking alongside their brave men. comes to the door of the Rooming House. Inman looks back sees her, but almost immediately loses her in the crowd.

HILL --
EXT. BEHIND CONFEDERATE LINES, VIRGINIA. DAY
-- AND THE WOUNDED AND THE WRETCHED STRAGGLE ALONG THE
RAILROAD.

text: A TRAIN with the seriously injured snakes past the back o the Confederate lines -- its suburbs of supplies, arrivin and departing troops -- and into peaceful country. FIDDLE PLAYS, THEN A BANJO.

head_text.subj: INT. BOX CAR. DAY

text: A CROWDED WAGON. It's a cauldron, and those able smash th the wooden walls to make a breathing hole. Some have thei heads thrust out like crated poultry. INMAN IS IN THERE,  neck bandaged, its ugly seepage making a bloody necklace. The light plays black and white through the boarded sides the boxcar, flashing on Inman's face as he drifts in and of consciousness. He focuses and sees the strange head of STOBROD'S FIDDLE. Stobrod is serenading him, accompanied an angel-faced and extremely heavy child-man, PANGLE, who grin of delight seems permanent even in this claustrophob grim world. Inman is panicked, puts a hand to push the fi away. His voice is a croak, spoiled.
I'm not dying.
(to Pangle) What'd he say?
Says he ain't about to die.
(to Inman) Truth to tell they say you are,  Soldier. We'll meet again, in the  better world.
He changes his tune, and the tempo, finding a foot-slappi rhythm, the two musicians grinning at each other. Inman l back into unconsciousness. The rhythm becomes a hammering sound...

head_text.subj: EXT. CHAPEL, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY

text: -- AS A MAN HAMMERS A TINTYPE OF HIS SON'S FACE into the  wooden porch of the Chapel, where it joins many other  portraits of those lost to the war. Monroe presides. One the slaves from Black Cove holds the ladder for the berea father. Other families wait, with their own daguerreotype mount. It's a memorial service without bodies. Riders approach. Home Guard. Teague brings his horse up  alongside Monroe at the Chapel door, tips his hat in  condolence to the bereaved families. With him is a young, intensely beautiful and flamboyant rider, BOSIE, his hair long, a single fingernail bizarrely overgrown. Somehow  sinister.

My condolences to you all. (he considers the  slave) Keep an eye on the negro. They want  what the white man got -- all of you  watch out your brave boys give their  lives to war and meantime your slaves  carry murder, rape and arson to your  firesides.
The only slaves within twenty miles  labor on my farm. They're good  Christians and I'll vouchsafe for  them.

head_text.subj: EXT. APPROACH TO BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Cold Mountain at its loveliest. The CABRIOLET with Monroe and his daughter heads towards the farm. At a bend they m a couple of riders, TWINS, from Teague's Home Guard, ridi furiously past them. Monroe reins in the trap and lets th thunder past before continuing on their way home. Monroe intrigued by Ada, as if he's never looked at her before.
What?
You're looking -- at this moment, I  don't know why -- you're looking  exactly like your mother.
Every time you see the doctor you  get melancholy.
He listens to my heart and I get  emotional.
He gives you alcohol and you get  emotional.
She squeezes his arm.
We commiserate about the folly of  this terrible war. (they ride in silence) Do you worry when there's no word  from him? (no response) From Mr. Inman?
Yes. But then I've tried counting  the number of words which passed  between Mr. Inman and me. (looking ahead, seeing  smoke) Is that a bonfire? So close to the  barns.
Then they see THE FAMILY OF SLAVES turn off the road as t cabriolet approaches, running away into the fields.
What's going on?
(shouting at the  disappearing slaves) Hey! Stop there! Hey!

Monroe gets out of the cabriolet and runs into the fields after the retreating family, who are carrying bundles, ch personal items, all loaded up. Ada has already taken the  reins and has driven up to the house. THE BARN IN WHICH T SLAVE FAMILY HAD LIVED IS ON FIRE. Monroe catches one of women, remonstrates with her. She's upset, distressed, on of her sons comes back, pushes Monroe to the ground. They hurry away. Monroe gets up, hurries to the fire.

head_text.subj: A FIGURE SWINGS IN THE HEAT OF THE FLAMES, HANGING FROM A

text: BEAM. Monroe spies it as he catches up with Ada.
Dear God.
No, Daddy, it's not real.
The figure swings round. IT'S AN EFFIGY, A GROTESQUE  CARICATURE OF A BLACK MAN.
(appalled) What is wrong with us all?
Ada turns and runs off.
I'll get help. (shouting over her  shoulder) Keep away from the flames.
Monroe stands and considers the flames. Ada turns back on more to see him -- a small man silhouetted against the bl

head_text.subj: INT. HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. DAY

text: INMAN lies; bandaged, eyes closed, in THE BALLROOM OF A  COLONIAL MANSION, co-opted as one ward of a Confederate  hospital. Rows of beds, the wounded and the dying, are lo between some vestiges of the room's former glory. SOME LOCAL WOMEN, conscious of their duty to the cause, a brought through by an exhausted doctor, who's lost all hi grace. The windows are open, but it's still insufferably  hot, the muslin curtains barely moving.
Most of these men will be dead by  the morning or, if they're stubborn,  by nightfall. I have other men outside  in the quadrangle waiting for the  beds.
The women try to process this, the attitude.
So, any kind word will be a blessing.
One woman is overpowered by the stench, gags.
It's the heat. I'm sorry. They rot.
The women begin to approach the beds.
Don't pray. If they're not God fearing  you can stir up a hornet's nest.
MRS. MORGAN, nervous, decent, sits next to INMAN. His mou is moving. She doesn't know what he's saying.
I'm sorry, you want water?
She bends to him again. His voice is a faint croak.
Pigeon River. Little East Fork.
The Doctor is on his exit, stops at the bed.
I'm sorry. I don't know what he's  saying.
They ramble. Names of loved ones.
(listening to Inman) Pigeon River. Is that a place? Cold  Mountain?
The Doctor shrugs, not a detective, moves on, stops at th man in the next bed. Has a brief look, calls to a nurse.
This man is dead.

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. LATE AFTERNOON

text: Monroe and Ada are outside, a picnic at the summer table, autumn leaves blowing up around them. Nearby the charred  skeleton of the barn. Ada gets up, clears away.
Thank you. (staying her for grace) For your Providence, Oh lord, we  thank you.
Amen. That was the last of the ham.
It was delicious.
I have to learn how to cook.
I was going to say something in  Chapel. Perhaps some of the womenfolk  will volunteer.
I can't have people coming here and  cooking for me!
It's my fault. I should have raised  you less like a companion and more  like a young woman. I'm sorry.
I'm not sorry, but I don't know how  we'll get through another winter.
Will you play me something? Something  peaceful while I look over my sermon.
Ada takes the dishes away. He gets out his papers, his pe and ink.

head_text.subj: INT. PARLOUR, BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK

text: ADA PLAYS THE PIANO. Chopin's Prelude in E Minor. Outside the garden, Monroe has adjourned to his striped campaign  chair, and is hunched over his notes. The door of the par is open and the music floats over to him as he works. Ada plays. A FEW SPOTS OF RAIN appear at the window. Then the steady drumming of a summer shower.
(still playing) Daddy, bring the tablecloth in with  you!
She plays some more. Monroe hasn't come in. The rain spla on to the window..
Daddy, come inside before you drown!
After a few more bars, she stops playing and, curious, go to the door. She stands at the doorway. MONROE'S SERMON I

head_text.subj: CAUGHT IN THE WIND AND BLOWS AROUND HIM, THE INK RUN TO

text: ABSTRACTIONS, his hand dropped and visible to Ada as, wit dread, she approaches. SHE CATCHES THE SODDEN PAPERS, CHA AFTER THEM, THEN REACHES HER DEAD FATHER. He's like a fish, his face shining with the rain, and gla eyed. She leans in to him, her head to his heart, then ru oblivious to the rain, her dress already drenched, runs d the lane.
Dear Mr. Inman...

head_text.subj: INT. HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. NIGHT

text: INMAN'S FACE as he drifts in and out of consciousness. Mr Morgan, the hospital volunteer, sits by Inman's bed. She  holds ADA'S UNOPENED LETTER, badly weather damaged, the p stuck together, the writing blurred where the ink has run
It's come to you by way of Virginia.
There are various dates, which she decodes.
It's not too recent -- written this  past winter. I'm afraid I can't read  who it's from. Dear Mr. Inman,

head_text.subj: INT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT

text: Ada is writing at her father's desk. A lonely room.
-- I'm still waiting, as I promised  I would, but I find myself alone and  at the end of my wits --

head_text.subj: INT. HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. NIGHT

text: Mrs. Morgan reads to Inman, trying to decipher the letter
-- at the end of my wits, so now I  say to you, plain as I can, come  back to me. Come back to me is my  request. (can't read the next  bit) Then something I can't read,  something, come back to me.
Inman is very still. Then, eyes glinting with determinati gives a TINY NOD.
By order of Zebulon Vance, Governor  of this great state of North Carolina:  any soldier turned deserter is guilty  of treason and shall be hunted down  like a dog.

head_text.subj: EXT. COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY

text: Ada walks down the hill from the Chapel. There is an abse of young people, but the older folk are gathered round th General Store where a UNIFORMED OFFICIAL is reading from document.
-- Any man takes in a deserter is  likewise guilty of treason.
The Official is flanked by Teague, Bosey and the twins, p up with self-importance. Ada has to walk around him to en the store.
The Home Guard is powered to enter  any place it sees fit, without notice  or constraint. Names of all deserters  will be posted in every town,  published in every newspaper.

head_text.subj: INT. GENERAL STORE, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY

text: The Official continues outside as Ada enters. Ada approac Mrs Castlereagh, the owner.
Is there a letter for me?
Nothing -- we're getting no post  through at all -- although if you  slip out back the material you ordered  has arrived.

They go to the back of the store, to a screened-off area. Mrs. Castlereagh hands her over a packet of material. The another, more furtive, transaction to take place. Mrs  Castlereagh hands over a second parcel as if it were  narcotics. Ada tears at the wrapping. It's a parcel of bo
If folks knew I was taking deliveries  from the North.
I know. Thank you so much.
The sooner we lose this war the  better. Already one boy gone, another  with his leg took off at the knee.  That's enough.
What do you hear?
All I know is they say not one boy  in ten from these mountains is coming  home again and most of them are  deserters.

head_text.subj: EXT. GENERAL STORE, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY

text: Ada emerges, almost collides with Teague. She wriggles pa him, tries to make her package invisible.

IT'S WINTER. A solitary RIDER jogs his horse through the  frost, towards Black Cove farm. Ada is working at a handpump, failing to coax water from well. She's wrapped in blankets. The farm is somewhat unk and so is she. The hem of her skirt is frayed. She rips a it tearing off a strip of material, which she binds aroun the handle in an attempt to thaw the mechanism. Then she  looks up to see the horseman approaching. It's Teague. Ad immediately heads inside the house. Teague arrives at the house, takes a brace of RABBITS fro his saddlebag. He heads for the gate. The gate needs oili the path is overgrown, he looks at the pump handle, the  abandoned pitcher. Ada opens the door, pinning her hair.
It's taken me too long, but I've  come to pay my respects.
Thank you.
(hands over the rabbits) I reckoned you might need fattening  up.
Ada takes them. She is very queasy with these dead animal
This house must bring bad luck. Killed  my granddaddy to lose it, then my  daddy died on account of not having  it, then your daddy died on account  of getting it. We should burn it  down.
Didn't somebody try?
Lot to manage without help. Need a  hand with that pump?
No.
I'm happy to volunteer.
But not to volunteer for the war?
The war? I wanted to go. But you  know: too old, too literate. Plus I  got no spleen. Lost it from a horse's  kick.
You've got no spleen.

That's the thing about an organ. You  don't know you need it till you lost  it. (suddenly busy with a  bayonet) I want to clear this path. I can  just as soon do it and talk as stand  around and talk. Then you can say  men beat a path to your door.
I'd really prefer it if you didn't  do that.
Would you rather I did my job? (scything at the path) See if there's any material I should  confiscate. For the war effort.
I was raised in the good manners of  the South where a gentleman doesn't  enter a house with a woman alone.

(now he's at the pump) Good manners didn't quite make it to  these mountains. If it don't yield  meat, or you can't sit on it, or  suck on it... (he gets the pump  going, water pours  out) And you're sleeping all right? These  cold dark nights?
I'm sleeping fine.
It's going to be a long hard winter.
He turns and stops at the gate, runs his hands through hi hair and uses the grease to ease the hinge. Then steps up onto his horse, and rides away. Ada watches him. Shudders

head_text.subj: INT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT

text: Ada comes into the kitchen. A weak oil-lamp reveals THE T RABBITS, partially covered on a plate, flies buzzing arou them, a little liquid leaking from them. Ada takes a knif and contemplates skinning gutting them. Suddenly she gath them up and runs out.

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT

text: ADA BURIES THE TWO RABBITS. The wind howls. She covers th little hole with soil and stones. Pumps out water to wash her hands. Thinks she hears a noise, listens, alert to an unfamiliar sounds, then hurries back to the house.

head_text.subj: INT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT

text: Ada comes inside, she closes the door. Locks it. Puts a c against it. Goes upstairs, to her bedroom.

head_text.subj: INT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT

text: Ada enters her bedroom. It's a chaos of books, clothes,  dishes. She closes the door, sets another chair against i Then drags her armchair up against that, books and papers spilling onto the floor. She props up Inman's portrait, o the chair, as if he were guarding her. Sits on the bed an desolate, begins to write:

head_text.subj: EXT. THE OCEAN BY THE HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. DAY

text: Should I imagine you are dead and,  that it is to your spirit I am  writing? No word from you in all  this time. If you receive this please  know I am here and warring, too,  with a faint heart.

THERAPY FOR WOUNDED SOLDIERS. Some of those convalescing  swim or are helped to paddle in the healing sea. There ar rudimentary wheelchairs. Inman, a long way from home, is  amongst those sitting in one of these, very still, grey a sick -- but alive. He pulls at the dressing on his neck,  exposing the still raw and livid wound to the sea air. Inman has his Bartram, his bookmark is the battered and f picture of Ada, which he considers, before continuing to  read. Behind him A HUNDRED SLAVES AT WORK IN THE FIELDS, and be them the Mansion which has become the hospital. A series bells, of shouts, and the slaves stop working, prepare fo the long walk home, congregating, then forming a line, he by the foremen. Inman eases his position to bend over and dip his bandage the seawater. He brings the wet bandage to his neck, cons the ocean, his fellow ragtag of wounded, the slaves, the  great fields, the Mansion. The whole meaning of this war  around him. A GRAVEL VOICE STARTS TO SING THE BLUES, CONT
