EXT. HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. DUSK

text: The men return to the Hospital. A BLIND MAN IS SELLING PE which he roasts over a small fire. HE'S SINGING AS --

head_text.subj: EXT. CHAPEL, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY

text: -- A tintype of OAKLEY is added to the Chapel's votives,  hammered in alongside Rourke and Butcher. There are fifty more images now, the paint flaking around them. The exter of the Chapel, three years on, has taken on the burden of recording history. There is no minister, no services, just the votives,  daguerreotypes or simply the names of those missing in ac accompanied by tiny vases of wildflowers. The town shroud in mist, and quiet.

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. SPRING. DAY

text: EVERYWHERE SIGNS OF PROFOUND NEGLECT, like a Grimm's fair tale of a deserted house. The fields are overgrown with w the gardens abandoned. The chickens have deserted the hen and are wandering around the outbuildings, scuffing at th packed dirt. Sally and Esco come up the overgrown path, avoiding the  chickens, and knock at the door.
Ada! Ada, It's Sally.

They're seen from ground level, through a boxwood, as the feet patrol the ground, turn away from the door, and then retreat, their voices drifting away. Ada is there, crouch in her hidey-hole, a blanket on the ground, her book. She wants to reveal herself, but is too embarrassed.
Will you look at the state of this  place!
Poor soul. She's got nobody and  nothing and three hundred acres of  misery.

During this a ROOSTER, black and gold, struts into the  boxwood. As the rooster approaches, Ada shudders, tries t shoo it away without alerting her presence. Ada peers thr the boxwood as Sally and Esco close the gate and recede. rooster comes at her again. She rises up, kicking out at while he flares his wings, spurs flaying at her. Ada runs from the boxwood, tormented by the triumphant rooster, wh continues to fly and scratch, driving her into the house.

head_text.subj: INT. ADA'S BEDROOM BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ada dabs at the scratches, her dress rolled down to the w to reveal her arms and shoulders. Now she shucks off the  dress completely and tries to find a clean replacement. T isn't one, so she hunts through the overflowing laundry b for something less dirty.

head_text.subj: INT. MONROE'S BEDROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ada enters her father's room, wearing undergarments. Everything as he left it and, in contrast to the rest of house, extremely tidy. She opens a wardrobe, finds one of his coats, puts it on. It's much too big, and she rolls u the sleeves, catches her pinched face and disheveled face a swivel mirror. She turns the mirror away and the image  swings into --

head_text.subj: EXT. GATES OF HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. DAY

text: -- the figure of Inman walking, frail, grey. A kind of  lurching walk, as if his balance isn't guaranteed. He get close to the gate and interests a Guard, on the lookout f would-be deserters. A BLIND MAN IS SELLING PEANUTS which roasts over a small fire. He's always singing. Inman  approaches. When Inman speaks, his voice is a croak.
Getting better all the time.
Seems that way.
I wouldn't hurry. War's almost done.
Where'd you take your wound?
Before I was born. Never saw a thing  in this world, not a tree a gun or a  woman. Though I put my hand on all  three. Couple of things I felt back  there I'd sure liked to have had a  long look at.
He's shoveling some peanuts into a twist of paper.
What would you give for that? To  have your eyeballs back for ten  minutes?
Ten minutes! Wouldn't give an Indian  head cent. I fear it might turn me  hateful.
That's sure what seeing's done to  me.
That ain't the way I meant it. You  said ten minutes. It's having a thing  and then the loss I'm talking about.
Then we don't agree. There's not  much I wouldn't give for ten minutes  of someplace.
Someplace or someone.
Same difference.
You watch yourself. They're shooting  men who take themselves a walk.

head_text.subj: EXT. TREE PROMENADE, CHARLESTON. DAY

text: Inman and a bunch of other walking wounded make their way under supervision, towards the town. The grandeur of the  approach, the carriages. The sorry state of the soldiers.

head_text.subj: INT. COURTHOUSE, CHARLESTON. DAY

text: TWO GREAT TRESTLE TABLES, LOADED WITH CLOTHES. Underneath the tables, boots -- laced together, origins various. The charitable womenfolk are helping match clothes to recover soldiers, some of whom are still on crutches, or in  wheelchairs. Inman finds a black dresscoat, some pants, a pair of boots. He accumulates a little pile. On his way o AN ELDERLY AND STAUNCH CONFEDERATE GENTLEMAN shakes his h and gives him an apple from the barrel.

head_text.subj: EXT. TEMPORARY BARBERSHOP, CHARLESTON. DAY

text: Inman emerges from the Courthouse and joins the line for shave at the makeshift barbershop set up outside the  Courthouse. Two barbers, two chairs. A VERY ELEGANT SQUAR

head_text.subj: SOME STUCCO-FRONTED BUILDINGS, A GLIMPSE OF THE MONEYED S
IN SHARP CONTRAST TO THE MODEST TOWN OF COLD MOUNTAIN. AN
AUCTION HOUSE OPPOSITE ADVERTISES SLAVES, CATTLE, LAND...

text: Next.
Inman settles in the seat. The Barber contemplates his sc beard, the livid, scabbed wound on his neck.
(nervous) I'll cut your hair, but I ain't about  to shave you. That thing opens up,  your head's liable to falloff.

It is almost dawn. The window by Inman's bed is a frame g onto the still dark world. The Night Guard passes by on i patrol of the perimeter. A CLEAN-SHAVEN INMAN IS FULLY DR UNDER THE COVERS. He gets his hat, pushes his book into h knapsack and, with one step up, WALKS OUT OF THE WINDOW A INTO THE WORLD.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE OCEAN BY THE HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. DAWN

text: Inman, his footprints in the sand, as he hurries along by the edge of the ocean, away from the hospital...

head_text.subj: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY

text: -- as Ada walks, the wind kicking up around her, past the Swanger place. She's bent and curiously dressed in her  father's coat.
Ada...
Sally Swanger calls out from the field. She's concerned a Ada's gaunt, ragged appearance. Ada waits for her approac
You're skinny as a whippet, girl --  you're coming indoors with me.
I can't. I'm not -- I need to clean  some clothes.
Great God, you ever looked at my  husband! I can't get him to wear  decent Church clothes Christmas  morning. Hang on to me, the wind'll  blow you over.
And she folds her arm into Ada's. They walk up the lane.

head_text.subj: INT. SWANGER FARM. AFTERNOON

text: Ada eats. Esco across from her contemplating her evident  appetite, the oversized man's jacket. Sally ladles more f onto Ada's plate.
Don't go back to that dark house.  There's a bed here, least till our  boys get home.
That your daddy's coat?
I was saying to Sally, I wasn't  expecting to be visiting, so...
Don't suit you.
He starts to chuckle, then Ada, too, then Sally.
I can't get up to your place this  week. (of Sally) She's mad at me --
I don't expect -
-- more than I can do to keep this  place half-managed. I'm ready-to  stop, I tell you. I just want to sit  on my porch with Sal, watch my boys  in the field, holler good job! every  hour or so.
What about your people in Charleston?

There are no people. And no money.  My father had some bonds and  investments. They're worthless now,  of course, the war has... they're  not worth anything. (they look at each  other) I love it here. In spite of  everything.
And waiting on a feller.
A look from Sally.
Look down our well. (Sally's disgusted  with him) She should! Look down our well with  a mirror, you'll see the future.  S'what they say. (to Sally) You do it! Don't make that face.
I know it ain't rightly Christian,  but it's what folks do, like when  they dangle a needle over the belly  to see if you're carrying a boy or a  girl.
What kind of mirror?

head_text.subj: EXT. YARD, SWANGER FARM. LATE DAY
AN IMAGE
BE A CORRIDOR OF TREES. THE SUN LOW AT ONE END, THE SILHO
OF A FIGURE WALKING SLOWLY FORWARDS, A SUDDEN DISTURBANCE
CROWS.

text: Ada is bent backwards over the well, a hand mirror glinti down into the blackness. The reflection is elusive agains the bright evening sky, the sun almost set, and low.
See anything?
I don't know.
I tried many a time, never saw a  dickybird.

The image is clearer. The trees sharpen, the figure walki the steep incline of the corridor, all fiercely black and white as if it were a carpet of snow and black hieroglyph of trees, and crows flying. The trick of the glass and th watery disc of the well surface. A buzzing in Ada's ears, something like a distant music. Then the figure seems to  suddenly pitch forwards, but at that moment, Ada -- cante over, getting dizzy has to move and the image flies away, replaced with the sky, the flash of the setting sun.
You all right?
Ada's faint. She sits up, blank, a little shaken.
Yesterday I found myself crouched  over a well like a mad woman, which  I suppose I have become

head_text.subj: EXT. PLANTATION. DAY

text: Inman walks along an expanse of marshland. Great cranes f heavily over him.
-- and staring down into its secrets,  I thought I saw you there, walking  back to me --

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. LATE AFTERNOON

text: Ada is writing in her father's campaign chair, a blanket  wrapped around her, a rake propped next to her.
-- or wished I did.
That cow wants milking.

Ada looks up from her writing with a start. She covers he letter, guiltily, instinctively. In front of her, at the  gate, is A YOUNG RAWBONED, FERAL WOMAN, OF INDETERMINATE  ORIGINS. She is barefoot, and dressed in a hand-dye_ shif of blue. Her name is RUBY.
If that letter ain't urgent, the cow  is -- is what I'm saying.
I don't know you.
Old Lady Swanger says you need some  help. Here I am.
Ada is instantly defensive, intimidated.
I need help, I need, I do need help,  but I need a laborer -- there's  plowing and rough work and -- I think  there's been a misunderstanding.
What's the rake for?
The rake?

Ain't for gardening, that's for sure.  Number one -- you got a horse I can  plow all day. I'm a worker. Number  two there's no man better than me  cause there's no man around who ain't  old or full of mischief. I know your  plight.
My plight?

Am I hard to hear cause you keep  repeating everything. I'm not looking  for money, never cared for it and  now it ain't worth nothing. I expect  to board and eat at the same table.  I'm not a servant. Do you get my  meaning?
You're not a servant.
People'll have to empty their own  night jars, that's my point.
Right.
And I'm not planning to work while  you watch neither.
Right.
Is that a yes or a no?
(looks at Ruby) Yes.
There's half the day yet. Let's make  a start. My name's Ruby. I know your  name.
The rake: there's a rooster devil,  I'm sure of it. He's Lucifer himself.  I go near him he's at me with his  spurs.
I despise a flogging rooster. Where  is he?
Ada gets up, nods to the corner of the yard. Ruby goes ov The Rooster gathers himself up for a new opponent.

head_text.subj: IN ONE MOVEMENT SHE PICKS UP THE BIRD AND TWISTS OFF ITS
HEAD.

text: Let's put him in a pot.

head_text.subj: EXT. CORNFIELDS. DAWN

text: Inman's walking on a track which passes through cornfield the crop high and thick around him. He stops, hearing  something. Riders. He wades into the field, seeking cover the tall crop, lying in the dirt. Horses appear. HOME GUA

head_text.subj: MEN ON PATROL, A CHAIN GANG OF PRISONERS

text: IN TOW, A COUPLE OF FEDERAL SOLDIERS. They have dogs, whi sniff and growl, intrigued by the fields, called back by Home Guard. Inman waits until they're well out of sight. AS HE GETS T

head_text.subj: HIS FEET IN THE GREAT FIELDS, ANOTHER BODY APPEARS, THEN
ANOTHER, THEN ANOTHER, THEN ANOTHER, ALL SLAVES ON THE RU

text: DOTTED AROUND THE FIELD. He walks to the road, paying no  heed to them. They assemble, paying no heed to him and mo off in the opposite direction. Inman turns, looks at them
Hey! (they stop, turn) I'd pay a dollar for an egg. A piece  of cheese.
They look at him, then continue on their way.

location: ADA'S BEDROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. PREDAWN

text: Ada wakes up to persistent knocking.
Ada? Ada? You up?
Yes. (opening her eyes) It's still dark.
Tell the cows that. It's late.
Ada enters blearily, clutching her novel. Ruby already bu
I have to eat something.
Then you have to get up earlier. (at Ada's book) What's that?
A novel.
(heading outside) You want to carry a book carry one  you can write in --

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DAWN

text: Ruby emerges, followed by Ada, chewing on a tomato.
-- we got our own story. Called Black  Cove Farm: a catastrophe.
She looks back at Ada for a reaction.
I can spell it, too. C-a-t-a-s-t-r-o- phe. Learned the same place you did,  in the schoolroom. That's one of the  first words they taught me. Ruby  Thewes, you are a ca-t-a-s-t-r-o-p-h- e...
They're heading for the stable.

head_text.subj: INT. STABLE, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ruby's already pitching hay. Turns to Ada.
You mucking out?
Ada half-asleep, obedient, stunned by this energy.

Three years I was in school before  my daddy -- saying God rest his soul  is like wishing him what he had in  life, cause he lived to rest, he was  born tired -- before my daddy decided  there was better use for my backside  than have it sat all day in front of  a blackboard.

head_text.subj: EXT. A FIELD OF WEEDS, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ruby dictates a list to Ada as they bustle along.
Number One -- layout a winter garden  for cool season crops: turnips,  onions, cabbage, greens.
Ada scribbles, walks, scribbles.
Ruby up a ladder, inspecting the roof.
Number Two: patch the shingles on  the barn roof. Do we have a maul and  froe?
(writing, holding the  ladder) Maul?
M-a-u-l.
I have no idea.

head_text.subj: INT. COLD HOUSE, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ruby cleans out leaves and detritus from the stone channe allowing the stream to flow free and cool.
Number three: clay crocks for  preserves. Tomatoes. Beans. Jams.

head_text.subj: EXT. BOTTOM FIELD, BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK

text: Ruby doing her version of soil analysis, scrunching the e tasting it, spitting it out. Ada makes a face.
Clear and turn this field. No harm  done letting it go fallow, now we'll  do well.

head_text.subj: EXT. OUTBUILDINGS, BLACK COVE FARM. AFTERNOON

text: Ruby looks up. Ada catches up with her.
Number fifteen
Sixteen.
Number sixteen: let's get a martin  colony going in the Gourd House.  Keep away crows. You got one thing  in abundance on this farm and that's  crows.
What's a Gourd House?

head_text.subj: EXT. APPLE ORCHARD, BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK

text: Ruby, delighted, contemplates the bounty of apples.
There's survival. On them trees. (turns to an exhausted  Ada) You got a cider press or would that  be wishing on a blessing?
Actually, yes, I think we do.
Ruby whoops, jogs away. Ada, exhausted takes a bite of an apple, watches her.

head_text.subj: EXT. A BLUFF. NIGHT
INMAN WALKS A ROCKY TRACK, FALLING AWAY TO THE RIVER AT O

text: SIDE, A STEEP CLIFF TO THE OTHER, the way itself broken a precarious, bad country to meet an enemy. Inman sees A LIGHT in the distance, a torch flicking in a out of view, like a star to follow. He stops, narrows his eyes to focus on the view, listening hard. He pulls out t Lemats.

head_text.subj: A MAN, ALL IN BLACK, A HORSE IN TOW, IS AT THE EDGE OF TH
GORGE.

text: The horse has a burden -- a sack or wrapped bundle draped over either side of the saddle. The attempts to heave the bundle onto his shoulders. He can't, and the bundle slips the ground, cover falling enough to glimpse an arm, a hea IT IS THE BODY OF A BLACK GIRL. The man tries again to li her. He's clearly upset, despairing, his hat comes off to reveal long, dandy's hair, all extravagant curls. He stag with the weight of the girl, heading for the lip of the d gorge. He kisses the girl again and again, cheeks, mouth, mumbli to her. He's at the edge now and can just let her go. THE INMAN'S GUN IS AT HIS TEMPLE.
Don't let go. Just back up, nice and  steady, do this all in reverse, you're  going to end up with her draped back  over your animal.
Don't pull that trigger. I am a man  of God.
I've killed several of them.
I mean I am God's minister.
What part of God's business is  throwing a woman down a gorge.
A slave woman, can you see that in  this light? She's black as a bucket  of tar.
He's retreating, on his way back to the horse.
Is she dead?
Drugged her. Like you would a  butterfly. And I care for her, that's  the heartbreak of it.
He has the girl back on the horse. Inman brings the torch to his face. It's tear-stained.
She's got my bastard in her belly.  What kind of pistol is that I never  saw the like of it?

head_text.subj: EXT. VEASEY TOWN. NIGHT

text: Inman leads the horse, with Veasey ahead of him, hands ti behind his back, desperate for a reprieve.
I'm begging you. It's better you  blowout my brains than return me to  this place.
Where does she live?
In our house. She sleeps in our  kitchen. You don't know me, friend,  but the good Lord punished me with  want. I am all appetite. That's all  I do all day is want: food, the female  parts...
Shut your mouth. I don't want a sermon  every time I ask a question.
They're in the town's main drag now. There's a Chapel and next to it, a small house.
This your place?
Dear God of misery.
You're going to put her back where  she sleeps.

I do that the Members will lynch me.  Consorting with a nigger, adultery,  siring a bastard while serving as  their preacher. We're a strict  congregation we've churched men for  picking up a fiddle on the sabbath.
So you reckoned to kill her.
Disgusted, Inman approaches the front door of the house.
There's a back door. Have pity.
And he leads Inman down a side path.

head_text.subj: INT. VEASEY HOUSE. NIGHT

text: Veasey comes in, now carrying the girl. Inman comes behin the gun trained on Veasey as he sets her down by the fire
(whispering) Thank you. I was going to do a  grievous wrong.
He looks longing at the girl as he puts the blanket aroun her shoulders. He turns to Inman.
You tasted dark meat? Sweet as  liquorice. I think I should go back  up to my wife. She wakes at the  slightest noise.
Inman is incredulous that he thinks he can just go to bed
You find me some paper and a pen.

head_text.subj: EXT. CHAPEL, VEASEY TOWN. DAWN
INMAN HAS TIED A VERY DISTRAUGHT VEASEY TO A TREE IN FRON

text: OF HIS CHAPEL. Inman is pinning a sheet of paper above  Veasey's head. It's covered in handwriting. A dog barks.
You're not entitled to judge me!  You're nothing but an outlier, plain  as daylight!
Inman has pulled a handkerchief from Veasey's jacket. He  stuffs it into his mouth, cutting this diatribe short. An then he walks away leaving Veasey tied to the tree, cursi through the handkerchief.

location: ADA'S BEDROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. PREDAWN

text: Ada asleep. Ruby enters, shattering the calm.
Morning. Pigs: you have any loose in  the woods?
No. What? No. We bought our hams.
There's a world more to a hog than  the two hams! Lard, for example,  we'll need plenty --
She picks up some discarded laundry, contemplates the  overflowing laundry basket.
The catastrophe of Ada Monroe's  laundry. (marching out) I can feel you shutting your eyes.

head_text.subj: EXT. BOTTOM FIELD. BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ada and Ruby working with the horse to make the beginning of A SPLIT RAIL FENCE. As they struggle with a heavy rail Ruby is testing Ada.
What's this wood?
I don't know. Locust?
Where's North?
North is, North is --
Name me three herbs growing wild on  this farm.

(frustrated with Ruby  and with herself) I can't! I can't! All right? I can  talk about farming in Latin. Will  that do? I can read French. I know  Harmony and Counterpoint. I know my  Bible. I can name the principal rivers  of Europe, but don't ask me to name  one stream in this county. I can  embroider, but I can't darn, I can  arrange cut flowers, but I can't  grow them. If a thing has a function,  if I might do something with it, it  wasn't considered suitable.
Why?
Ruby, you could ask why? about pretty  much everything to do with me.
They manage to get the first line of rail set down.
This fence is about the first thing  I've ever done that'll produce an  actual result.
So you never wrapped your legs around  this Inman?
An old-fashioned look from Ada...

head_text.subj: EXT. SUNKEN FOREST. DAY

text: Inman finds himself in A SUNKEN FOREST OF PINE. He moves  warily, his beard longer, his figure gaunt, his clothes  weathering to a uniform smudge of charcoal. He hears DOGS BARKING IN THE DISTANCE, FAINT SHOUTS. He p up his pace, skirts round the swampy lake.

head_text.subj: EXT. CAPE FEAR RIVER. DUSK

text: Inman comes to the bank of a HUGE RIVER. The water, as th light begins to go, is the color of mud, with bubbles,  belching to the surface, full of ugly prominent. Inman is almost jogging now, an ear tracking his still distant  pursuers. The river is too wide to contemplate swimming a now it begins to curve left, forcing him -- against his  judgment, to circle back. He approaches A SMALL JETTY. A sign: Ferry $5. Yell Loud. On the far bank there's A CABIN ON STILTS above the highw mark. Inman calls out, reluctantly, his voice still a kin of growl. Then again. A TINY FIGURE steps out of the cabin and waves before jum into a small canoe. The canoe heads against the current, rower's back bent with the effort. As the canoe approache Inman sees that the ferryman is, in fact, A YOUNG GIRL, n eighteen. She doesn't look at him. He produces five dolla She eyes the bill with contempt.
For five dollars I wouldn't give a  parched man a dipper of this  riverwater.
Sign says ferry, five dollars.
This look like a ferry? My Daddy's  dead, or gone off to the Federals,  don't matter which. I'm the way across  now.
What's the name of this thing?
Nothing but the mighty Cape Fear  River, is all.
A dog barks in the distance. Getting closer. Inman turns the sound. The Ferrygirl is well aware of her leverage.
Nobody crosses this water unless  they're running from someplace. Some  cross one way, some the other: makes  no difference, they're all running.  You want to wait for your friends?
I can give you thirty dollars script.
Let's go.
Hey! Hey! Wait!

Inman is astonished to see VEASEY stumble out of the tree His head is shaved, his face bruised and swollen, his clo castoffs and ill-fitting, cinched at the waist with rope. stumbles towards Inman, urging him to get on with the jou
Keep going. We're both in trouble.
He gets straight into the canoe.
No. Get out.
It's Homeguard. Made me tell them  all about you.
I should have shot you when I had  the chance.
Shouts, more barking. Inman jumps in the canoe, and they' off. The Ferrygirl turns the boat around, rows them away  from the jetty with the grace of someone doing something the thousandth time.
I'm not looking for revenge, by the  way. For what you did to me. No, I'm  a Pilgrim now, like you, traveling  the road, paying our dues, relying  on the kindness of strangers.
You're nothing like me and the last  thing I want right now is a  conversation.

(to Ferrygirl) You recall Job in the scriptures? I  will give free utterance to my  complaint. I will speak in the  bitterness of my soul. That's our  friend here... (to Inman) They cut off my hair. Which was hard.  I was vain about my hair. (to Ferrygirl) I had good curls. But I deserved it.  I'm the Reverend Veasey. Have I seen  you in church?
Inman sits, scouring the bank for sign of his pursuers. T sun is sinking fast.

I'm saving for a cowhide, and when I  get it I aim to get a saddle made,  and when I get me a saddle I'll save  for a horse, and when I got a horse  I'll throw on the saddle, and then  you won't see my sorry ass round  this swamp again.
She has no love for the river. Another gurgle of viscous  bubbles around the canoe.
What's that?
Catfish. 'gator. Keep your hand in  the boat. Already looks like some  critter chewed his neck. (she looks at Inman) Thirty more dollars, we can go to  the cabin. I'll pull this dress over  my head.
(excited) Have we got thirty dollars?

A sharp sound, a tiny thwack of ball on meat. The Ferrygi SUDDENLY SLUMPS BACK and falls into the water. Veasey grabs out at the oar, but it goes, too. The girl s quickly, A BLOODY GAP to the side of her head. Inman, on knees and stretching, can't help her. Then a second noise A HOLE THE SIZE OF A FIST appears in the canoe, just at  waterlevel. Water pours into the canoe. Dogs bark, and no FIGURES are visible at the jetty. HOME GUARD. One of them has a sniper's rifle and is loading for a third shot. Inm can see him sighting the rifle. They lie flat in the cano ANOTHER GREAT FIST OF WOOD is gouged out. Now the boat is almost full of water. Veasey spits out a foul mouthful. I ROCKS THE CANOE AND LETS IT TURN OVER ONTO THEM, Veasey  surfaces from under it, clutching the wood as a raft, but the canoe CATCHES INMAN A BLOW TO HIS HEAD and he sinks.  Veasey hauls him to the surface and, surprisingly strong, holds him with one fist, the boat with the other, lets th current take them, pulling them under, then up, under, th up, but clinging on, as the rifle continues to deliver it assault, another shot into the boat, another into the wat near to Veasey's arm. THE GIRL'S BODY comes by them, carried by the river, the  dress billowing out almost covering her head. The sun has gone, the light fading, the canoe sliding downriver away  from their aggressors.

head_text.subj: EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CAPE FEAR. NIGHT

text: In the moonlight, the canoe drifts into the muddy bank an Veasey drags a half-drowned Inman to land, both of them  retching with the vile river water. AN ALLIGATOR eases in the river not ten feet from where they lie, lungs heaving They get up. Veasey to his feet, Inman to his knees.
You okay?
Inman nods, coughs. And Veasey AIMS A KICK at Inman's hea knocking him back into the mud.
Jesus, god!
I figure that righteous, given our  history. Otherwise I'd bear a grudge  on our journey.
There's nowhere I'm going with you  except to Hellfire!

head_text.subj: INT. ADA'S BEDROOM. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT

text: Ada, her hair plaited in a new and simpler configuration, working on Ruby's hair, while Ruby experiments with some  earrings. A pile of Ada's jewelry on the bed beside them.
Agricola poetis viam non monstrat.
Which means?
The farmer does not point out the  road to a poet.
Which means? Should be the other way  round
Which means, I suppose, which means  the poet should know where he's going.
(of Ada's hairdressing) It's no wonder you're helpless and  hopeless if it takes this long to  fix your hair. (of the Latin) Say some more.
Terra mutata non mutat mores. (can't believe she  knows all these  phrases by heart) It's appalling what's in my head.
It's appalling what's in my head?
No, it means: A change of place does  not change a character.
Well that's surely true even in  English.
You can keep those earrings.
We can't keep anything.
I have to keep the bangles. They  were my mother's.
Well that's all. The rest is for  trading. Else they can bury you in  your finery.
(of her hair) You're done.
There's a small mirror on a stand. It has Inman's picture stuck in it. She picks it up, removing the tintype, and  holding it up for Ruby to see her hairstyle.
Good God! Okay.
She takes the mirror and shows Ada her simple plait.
I like it.
Takes two minutes. That's what I  like.
She puts the earrings back in the pile.
How much do you love that piano?

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK

text: THE PIANO jangles down the rutted lane on the back of Mr. Roy's cart. Ada watches, A SMALL FLOCK of sheep milling a her in the path. Ruby is dragging a big sow towards the y Ada picks up one of two sacks and staggers towards the ho

head_text.subj: INT. KITCHEN, BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK

text: Ada arrives in the kitchen. They've got it under control  now, scrubbed and orderly. She puts the sack down next to another one. Her hands are calloused, the finger nails cr and ruined, stripes of earth under them. Ruby comes in,  struggling with the last sack, pleased.
We're careful we'll get through the  winter now. I made old man Roy give  me ten of those sheep on account of  I said they were so small put together  they were no bigger than six proper  sheep.
My father always wanted sheep on  this land.
I'm sorry you had to lose your piano.  I cut off my hair once, for money.  My daddy got two dollars for it.  Made a wig for a rich feller in  Raleigh.
They're working as they talk, taking the sacks into the  larder, putting out stuff for the evening meal.

Stobrod called himself a musician --  my daddy -- he could play six tune  on a fiddle. Got himself shot dead  at Petersburg. I was like his goat  or some creature tethered to a post.  He left me once, up the mountains. I  was eight. He was gone over two weeks.
Oh Ruby.
(defiant) I was all right! He'd walk forty  miles for liquor and not forty inches  for kindness.
And your mother?

Never met her. We're the same in  that regard. He said she was -- he  told me a thousand stories -- she  was a wolf or an indian or a donkey.  Don't say much for him, except you  know he'd be fast to work up a sweat  on a tree if he thought there was  pleasure in it.
There's a pause. Ruby not easy with her emotions. Abruptl she jumps up.
There's cows to milk.

head_text.subj: EXT. RIVER, EN ROUTE TO SALISBURY. DAY

text: Inman stands in the river, hoping to catch a fish, trying concentrate. Veasey presides, complaining...

Used to be as regular as morning  prayers. Matter of fact I could set  my watch by my bowels. That beeswax  you fed me, day before yesterday, it  stops a man up. Open my gut now they'd  find turds stacked up like little  black twigs.

On a parallel track across the river, RIDERS... impossibl to say whether Home Guard or a Federal Raiding Party. Inm splashes out of the water, pushes Veasey down, silencing  him. The riders pass. Veasey spots something shining in the grass, picks it up. IT'S A LONG TWO-HANDED SAW.
Hey! Look at this! (flexing it) This is a good saw.
(getting up) It's not yours. You take it, you  make us another enemy. You're a  Christian -- don' t you know your  commandments?
You'll find the good Lord very  flexible on the subject of property.  We could do a lot with this saw...
Inman is vexed, walks away. Veasey follows, experimenting with the saw's music when flexed. Inman stalks on.

head_text.subj: EXT. NEAR A FORD. DAY

text: Inman way ahead, full of purpose. Veasey still has the sa trots to catch up.
Why you in such a hurry the whole  time? (no answer) Hurry or slow the destination is  always the same. It's only the journey  that is different. That's either in  the Good Book or I made it up.

Inman suddenly stops, scowling, puts up a hand, listens. Inman carefully scouts the track then, with great caution edges towards the river bank. A HEAVY SET MAN labours in the water. He's contemplating HUGE BLACK CARCASS OF A BULL which has slipped into the f and died. The man is wet and exasperated.
Good day to you!
The man turns, his spirit evidently lifted by the prospec of help. His name is JUNIOR. He's working on roping the  animal.
My old bull, wandered off and died  in this here creek. Fouled up our  water is how I found it.
Veasey is immediately an authority on bull removal.
This is a tricky one.
The three men contemplate the carcass, swatting away the  swarms of flies. Junior offers a swig from a jug of liquo Inman refuses, Veasey takes a long pull, shudders happily
The name for the Bull's member is a  tassel. I learned that and never  forgot it.
Reckon I need a train of mules.
(walking away) I'm getting an idea. My saw is the  remedy. Let's saw up some wood and  make levers.
Then what?
Lever him out. This'll work!
He walks into the wood.
Where you two sports heading?
(inscrutable) I don't know where he's heading. I'm  going down the road. And I got a  good way to go before nightfall.
(acknowledging his  attitude) Charitable of you to make a stop.  Ain't for me to be curious.
(emerges from the  woods) How do you work this damn thing?
(to Veasey) Give me that saw. (to Junior) Come on.
He takes the saw, walks to the bull, gets on one side,  indicates Junior should go to the other.
Let's do this in chapters.

And they begin to SAW OFF THE BULL'S NECK. LATER, and they're in A VILE STEW OF BLOOD AND INNARDS. T stomach opens and its contents gush into the creek. Vease is disgusted, draws back. The two other men haul up the r of the animal onto the banks. They're exhausted.
You might want to leave off that  water for a day or two.
There'll be a tang, I'd imagine.

head_text.subj: EXT. TRACK APPROACHING JUNIOR'S CABIN. EVENING

text: Junior, Inman and Veasey come around a bend and there's A BIG CABIN LOOMING. It's in such poor repair that one end slipped from the stones which serve as it's foundation an STANDS BADLY TILTED OVER. Junior roots up another hidden of liquor, which he drinks from, then hands to Veasey.

There's my place. Hope you can stomach  a yard chock-full of females. Brought  my woman home, she showed up with  her three so-called sisters and their  brats. The noise in that place is  something awful. It's why I go  hunting.
(considering the wild  camber) Looks a bit crooked.
It is on a bit of a tilt. Them  females. They all roll down one end  each night!
-- Roll me over!
-- In the clover
One good fart -- that'll tip over!
They guffaw, delighted in the alcohol haze. Veasey sudden exclaims, hand in the air, rushes into the bushes.
Oh God of my God! Hallelujah!  Hallelujah!
What's up?
The Israelites! The tribes of Israel  are about to flee from the banks of  Egypt! Hallelujah!
(explaining to Junior) He's got a shit coming on. It's  overdue.
(bewildered) And he's a Preacher? Like a Christian?
Like a Christian.
Good God.

head_text.subj: EXT. JUNIOR'S CABIN. DUSK

text: The three men arrive at the yard. DOGS AND CHILDREN MILL  AROUND THE VISITORS. FOUR WOMEN COME OUT, one after the o each of them in simple shifts which seem to emphasis thei voluptuousness, or so it seems to Veasey. They freely sta
These two boys is stopping for supper.  They're on the road to Atonement.
The women consider the men, then disappear back inside.
Atonement is not a place.
So what is it when it's at home?
Those are fine examples of the female.
Take them all and leave the saw. Be  a sight more use.
(reappearing) If they want to get in a tub there's  an hour before food.
They love to scrub a man. (to Shyla) Put the water on the boil. (back to the men) It's my liquor, gets their titties  swinging.
(excited) God damn! (to Inman) I was right about sheep droppings  those stools -- like rock hard. Quite  astonishing.

head_text.subj: INT. SMOKEHOUSE AT JUNIOR'S CABIN. DUSK

text: No real furniture. Veasey is shaving. Inman stows his kna behind the woodburning stove, on which a big kettle of bo water steams away. Then he gets in the tub, his back to t door. Shyla comes in, brings the kettle over to the tub, pours the steaming water. She appraises Inman. It's intensely  sexual.
That's battered flesh. (of his neck wound) I could work a finger in there.
He's a hero. Took that wound at  Petersburg.
He doesn't know what I am. (uncomfortable with  her stare) Thanks.
(to Veasey) He's shy, ain't he?
Wait up a few minutes, I'll be in  that tub, then we'll see who's a shy  one.
I want to poke my thumb in his holes.
A second woman comes to the door. Dolly.
Lila says supper's up.

head_text.subj: INT. JUNIOR'S CABIN, NIGHT

text: LILA, JUNIOR'S WIFE, spoons out stew from a vast pot. The table crammed with customers -- her three sisters, the th men, the herd of dogs and filthy children. Nobody speaks. Each time Lila bends over to spoon out of the pot, her  cleavage strains against the flimsy fabric of her dress.  Veasey's mesmerized. Inman is also getting drunk, his eye increasingly glazed. When Lila makes to sit down next to  Junior, he slides a hand up her dress, exposing a naked  buttock, which he strokes and pinches as he pulls away.
Hey!
Junior grins, looks over at Inman, then nudges Veasey.
He's gone now. Look! His eyes have  gone.
(vaguely, drunk) What?
Dolly?
S'me.
Dolly, Lila, Shyla and Mae. That's a  poem. That's a poem.
He begins to recite, has a verse in his mind.
Dolly, Lila, Shyla and Mae (but he can' t summon  it) Da-da da-da da-da dae... (vague) ...there's a poem there.
I'm leaving soon as I'm full.
Really. Goodbye.
Got a bunch of traps needs visiting.  I'll be back tomorrow, before dark.  You'll still be here?
That's my fervent prayer.
My house is your house.
(suddenly) Like to wash their hands and pray.
Say again?
Dolly, Lila, Shyla and Mae.
That's Job. Don't say much but even  liquored up there's a preacher in  him.
Inman gets up suddenly, sways.
I'll say my goodbyes, got miles and  miles to go before sunset. (head spinning) I'll just quickly lie down.
And he stumbles over to the fire where he instantly curls up.
I'm heading for that smokehouse and  I'm ready to be washed clean of my  dirt.
He gets up, wanders out of the door. Junior's eyes glint. jerks his head towards the girls then in the direction of the smokehouse.
You go tend to him. (to Lila) I'll be seeing you.
He picks up his gun and leaves Dolly gathering up the chi and herding them out.
Come on you -- get!
Shyla stays, Mae having gone off after Veasey. Lila waits until the children have gone. They consider Inman supine the fire.
He's mine. You can go rub yourself  off on the Preacher. (of Inman) Gonna make him hug me till I grunt.

Lila shepherds Shyla out, shuts the door, swigs from the  jug, walks over to Inman, then turns to the big table and pushes pots and plates way down to one end to make a play field. Then she bends over the prostrate Inman.
Hey!
Inman stirs, glazed.
(kneeling down to him) You want to see what Mamma's got for  you?

head_text.subj: SHE SLIPS A SLEEVE OF HER DRESS TO REVEAL A FULL BREAST.

text: Inman is drunk, doesn't think he's awake. She takes her b to his mouth, and Inman suckles. Then she puts his hands  under the dress which rides up as his hands move between legs. She's naked.
That's good. Ain't that sweet?

head_text.subj: SHE PULLS INMAN TO HIS FEET, KISSES HIM, THEN TURNS HER B
AND LIES FACE DOWN ON THE TABLE, HER BARE ASS UNDULATING
THE AIR.

text: You just get on and ride me all the  way to China.
He doesn't move, except to sway, eyes glazed. She turns.
You shy? You need a hand? (goes to his buttons) Let's have a look see what we can  muster.

She's kneeling now, her dress hunched up around her middl working the front of Inman's pants. He's in a swoon,  surrendering to her, getting aroused, his hand cupping he head. ON CUE, THE DOOR CRASHES OPEN AND HE'S STARING DOWN THE BARREL OF JUNIOR'S SHOTGUN. As Lila turns, Junior KICKS HER violently in the head,  knocking her over.
You little bitch! Look at you! Cover  yourself up!
HEAD. Inman falls back. Junior goes to the door and whist

head_text.subj: AND WITH THAT THE ROOM FILLS UP WITH A GROUP OF HOME GUAR
BRISTLING WITH WEAPONS AND PURPOSE. THEY SEIZE INMAN, DRA
HIM OUT AS JUNIOR SPITS AND KICKS AT HIM.
INT. SMOKEHOUSE AT JUNIOR'S CABIN. NIGHT

text: Lila enters the smokehouse, hand to her bruised head. VEA

head_text.subj: ON THE FLOOR, WITH DOLLY ASTRIDE HIM, HIS ARM CRUSHING A

text: NAKED MAE INTO AN EMBRACE. He considers Lila, beams:
I had a special prayer you'd come  visit.

head_text.subj: THREE MEN BURST IN BEHIND HER, RIFLES RAISED.
EXT. JUNIOR'S CABIN. NIGHT

text: Veasey led out, a CHAIN GANG waiting -- a bedraggled  collection of prisoners, slaves, deserters -- and now INM Veasey is joined to the line. It starts to rain.

head_text.subj: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY

text: Ruby and Ada at the door of the Swanger house. They both  wear Monroe's clothes by now, like two little men. THEY'R CARRYING A SMALL SACK, A PIE UNDER A CLOTH. Ruby hammers the door, a little impatient. Sally Swanger opens it, has decode who it is under the clothes, the hats.
Ada Monroe and Ruby Thewes! Look at  you both!
Look at us both what?
Like a coupla scarecrows after a  thunderstorm.
We need a scarecrow, birds eating up  half our winter garden.
Sally's right. We should both stop  toiling and stand a while with our  arms stretch out. I'll volunteer.
We got something for you.
For all your kindness. Coffee. And a  pie.
That's real coffee. It ain't hickory  and dirt.
(taking the gifts) Thank you both. (of the pie) Ruby, I look forward to this. We all  do. Esco and me.
(grinning at Ada) She made it.
I made it.
Good God in Heaven.
(by way of  recommendation) I'm still alive.
Sally's strangely awkward, lingering at the door, staring the gifts...
We'll be getting along.
(nodding) I know Esco's going to be real sorry  he missed you. You all take care.
They all kiss, then the girls walk back down the path. Ru is vexed.
That strike you as odd?
What?
Stood at her front door?
Sally?
Number one -- I know that woman all  my life. I never stood outside her  house -- she'd invite a wolf inside  if it knocked on the door.
Perhaps, I don't know, perhaps she  was busy.
Number two -- Old Man Swanger was  inside that house: I could smell his  pipe burning. Number three -- look  at these fields.
What about them?
She contemplated the stubble fields they're passing.
We came by here a week ago, they  were waist high in hay.

head_text.subj: EXT. A PATH. DRIVING RAIN. NIGHT

text: The Home Guard ride, bent under their oilskins, as the ra tips down. Between the horses, unprotected and drenched,  their prisoners trudge along the muddy path. Inman and Ve among them. Veasey has grown some beard. AN OLDER MAN COLLAPSES, lies where he falls, not moving. There's a domino effect and so Inman falls on top of him. picks himself up, then tries to pull up the older man. He doesn't move.
He's dead.
The horses plough on. Inman shouts to BROWN, the leader.
This man's dead!
Nobody pays any attention. He has to drag the body.

head_text.subj: EXT. VEASEY TOWN. DAY
THE HOME GUARD ESCORT THE PRISONERS PAST VEASEY'S OLD CHU

text: More days have gone by and taken their toll on the prison Veasey and Inman are haggard and filthy and reduced. The  Home Guards stop for food, a wash, a break, chain the  prisoners to a horse rail. Citizens go by, Veasey knows them all. Some of them spit  contemptuously at the Deserters. None of them recognise  Veasey.
Am I so altered that they don't see  me?
Somebody walks by with a young child. Veasey looks at Inman.
I christened that child.
The child stops, looks without recognizing, is tugged awa from the chain gang by his mother. One of the other priso SHEFFIELD, leans in to Inman, his voice low.
I'm looking to get out of this. They  drag us back to fight -- we're just  target practice for the Federal boys.
You run, we're all running with you,  the lame and the stupid, of which we  number both.
Either way we're fucked. Run or don't  run.
Just give me some warning so I can  tell the guard -- I'm not getting  shot again for some cause I don't  believe in.
A GROUP OF SLAVES ARE WALKING BY, CARRYING SACKS. One of women is pregnant. Veasey studies the group, sees the pre woman, recognizes her.
(mesmerized) That's Rebecca. That's Rebecca. (he hisses) Rebecca!
In daylight it's apparent that Rebecca is a real beauty. turns at the sound of her name, stops, is confused. She s Veasey and approaches, appalled at his condition.
Mas?
Is it well with you? (Rebecca nods) I've been repenting for what I did.  I've walked the road of atonement.
Your curls is all gone.

head_text.subj: THE GUARD KICKS HIM.

text: Hey!
(holding his head, to  Rebecca) God Bless you.

Rebecca, reluctant, rejoins the other slaves, walks away  with them, but then turns back to look at Veasey. She cle cares about him. And seeing her has somehow broken his he He turns away from Inman, towards Sheffield.
I'm with you. I got a baby coming.

head_text.subj: EXT. RAILROAD TRACK. DAY

text: THE CHAIN GANG TRUDGES DOWN THE TRACK, horses on either s of them, steep banks forming a V for the railroad. A TRAI IS COMING. Brown rides up to the prisoners, herds them of the track. The train approaches quite slowly -- the boxca full of wounded soldiers. Some of the Home Guard dismount take out pipes. The prisoners wait, one of them sits down Sheffield says something to Veasey, who casually yanks up the sitting prisoner. Inman suddenly understands what's g to happen. The train is almost on them.
No!

But it's too late. SHEFFIELD JERKS FORWARD IN FRONT OF TH TRAIN, PULLING ALL THE OTHERS WITH HIM, their reluctance  tempered by the possibility of being crushed by the oncom train. SOMEHOW THE CHAIN GANG GETS ACROSS THE TRACK, stumbling a chaotic, the chains yanking tight, then loose, the tight  causing a collapse, the loose a recovery. They run alongside the train, blocking themselves from th fire of the Guard, Sheffield screaming tactics -- and the as the train starts to pull past them, they run up the ba now all as a unit scrambling to the steep summit.

head_text.subj: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE TRAIN THE HOME GUARD HAVE REMOUN

text: THEIR HORSES AND ARE RIDING HARD ALONGSIDE IT. Then they  have sight of the escaping prisoners silhouetted at the t of the bank like a line of paper dolls stretched out alon the ridge. Sheffield's yelling with adrenaline, Veasey jo in, elated. One of the guards raises a rifle, steadies hi on his horse, FIRES. He catches Veasey, who crumples, spi round and falling down the bank, until Inman uses all his strength and practically lifts him in the air. The chain  recovers and works back up the bank. But then A SECOND BULLET catches another prisoner and thi time the effect is catastrophic -- THE WHOLE GANG JUST FL OVER AND PLUMMETS DOWN THE BANK. The Home Guard approach, firing randomly at the bodies as they tumble into the dit by the side of the track. Until all movement ceases. Inma has a wound to his head which bleeds profusely, almost  completely covering his face. Brown arrives, considers th carnage.
Get these sacks of shit under the  ground.

head_text.subj: INT. BARN, BLACK COVE FARM. DAWN

text: Ada's milking. It's barely daylight. She's slowly becomin country girl. Ruby appears in the doorway.
Someone's been in the corncrib.
You sure?
It's a coon or possum. Scratched out  a fist hole in the side. This place!  I'm telling you -- we grow, others  eat. I'll go into town, take the  last of the cider and trade for a  trap.

head_text.subj: INT. MONROE'S BEDROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ada is in Monroe's bedroom, looks out as Ruby goes off to town, jugs of cider swung either side of the horse. Ada g over to Monroe's closet, pulls out some clothes.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE WINTER GARDEN, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ada buttons Monroe's dress coat and completes the SCARECR she's spent the day making, save for the hat, which she n fixes on, pushing in a hat pin to secure it. She's made a stern black thing and steps back to consider it. Horsemen come riding along the lane. It's Teague and his  men. He doesn't stop but raises his hat to Ada.

head_text.subj: INT. KITCHEN, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ada looks out at the Winter Garden. From that distance it really does look like her father out in the field, arms  outstretched as if waiting for her to run to him. She fin it unbearable, her tears coming, runs out into the fields attacks the scarecrow, pulling off the hat, the clothes..

head_text.subj: EXT. RAILROAD TRACK. MORNING

text: THE SOUND OF TINY BELLS. A misty drizzle. A GOAT snuffles around in the freshly turned dirt: A hand, pale and wet,  protrudes from the thin layer of earth covering the bodie of the murdered Chain Gang. SOMETHING SHIFTS UNDER THE DIRT, breaking the surface. In wedged under three or four corpses -- their limbs and cha wrapped around him, has regained consciousness. He coughs can't breathe properly, tries to work himself some air,  spitting out dirt. He makes a noise to distract the goat, rattling the chains. Inman rears up, the bodies slitherin off him, but even then the animal only retreats a yard or two. VEASEY SLIDES FACE UP, A BULLET IN HIS FOREHEAD LIKE MYSTICAL THIRD EYE. Inman feels a surprising loss and  tenderness. He heaves again, groaning with the pain of ne and old wounds.

head_text.subj: EXT. OLD MILL, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY

text: Ruby rides back from town along the river. An ugly lookin trap tied over the horses and three or four bulging sacks By an abandoned mill she sees the Home Guard under the tr She slows up.
What you looking to catch?
What?
With that trap.
We got some critter stealing our  corn.
Still but the two of you up there,  is it?
You know it.

When we get a cold night, camped  out, trying to keep the rule of law,  protecting girls like you from  Federals and deserters, that's a  thought warms us (to his men) ain't it? -- the two of you up there  on my Grand-daddy's farm, dressed in  men's clothes. Warms us right up.  What you got in the sacks? (to the men) Looks like human heads! Eh? Looks  like a bunch of heads. We got  competition!
Ruby rides on. She rides around the bend -- she's not far from the Swanger farm.

head_text.subj: EXT. RAILROAD TRACK. DAY

text: Goats, their bells tinkling, munch around the tracks. One them turns at a noise -- a GROTESQUE VISION -- A MOVING,  SEETHING MOUND OF DIRT. It's Inman, inching along the  embankment, the chain of dead bodies in tow, a macabre tu of war. He considers the goats, they consider him. He rea up and finds himself STARING DOWN THE BARREL OF A SHOTGUN

head_text.subj: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY

text: Sally is pinning out white sheets, they're filling out li sails in the afternoon wind. Ruby rides up. Sally seems a little vexed to see her. She walks down to the gate.
Ruby...
I'm not stopping, Sally. I'm not  snooping neither. Just you should  know Teague and his boys are lurking  down by Pigeon River, the old mill.
(after a beat) You tell Ada that was a good pie.
Ruby rides off. Sally watches, then goes inside the house her energy changing immediately, as if she might faint.

head_text.subj: EXT. MADDY'S CARAVAN. AFTERNOON

text: HARSH WHISTLES. A secret place, in the heart of a forest. There's the answering sound of SMALL BELLS, a chorus of t Inman is dragged into view on a makeshift litter. Goats  appear, they herd around the figure dragging the litter.  IT'S AN OLD WOMAN, silver haired, her face a leather map, her clothes leather, everything about her like old leathe HER NAME IS MADDY. She and Inman round a bend and there's Maddy's house -- A OLD CARAVAN, long grown into the ground and plaited with  vines and creepers. Inman tries to sit up. An old whisker BILLYGOAT butts up against Inman, knocks him down. Maddy  pays no attention to the struggle, heads inside her carav
Mind that Billy, he's the jealous  kind.

She emerges, with a bowl of water, rags, washes his face, pushing back his hair to look at his wound, puts a finger the gash on his neck professional in her appraisal. Inman barely conscious, he groans, trying to defend himself.
Pay no attention to me. What happened  to your head?
Fighting.
And your neck?
Different fighting.
You're the color of a cadaver. I'll  fix you. I can fix you up.
(speaking of his spirit) Mister -- you could fix me I'd be in  your everlasting debt.
Debts, fighting -- them words don't  mean much round here. For the record,  I'm a female of the species.

head_text.subj: EXT. BOTTOM FIELD, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ruby rides up to the farm. She rides past the winter gard admires THE SCARECROW -- WHICH NOW PARODIES ADA, the same outfit she once wore to visit Inman, the same dress, same hat. Ruby grins as Ada comes over from the field.
The hat's a nice touch.
Ruby gets off the horse, and they start unloading sacks.
You're quiet.
I cried for my Daddy. I dressed up  the scarecrow in his suit and he  came back, his arms out, said you  never cried enough, you never cried  enough.
Well now you did.

Then I thought, it's not my Daddy,  it's my sweetheart. I saw him once  that way, when I looked down Sally's  well. So I dressed the scarecrow in  the dress I wore the day he left. In  case his spirit flies over looking  out for me. (of the vicious looking  trap) That looks terrible.
Ruby opens the sacks.
Cabbages.
I bargained like Lucifer. We can  make all kinds of good eating.
Such as?
Cabbage. Slaw, sauerkraut, cabbage  soup, fried cabbage, stuffed  cabbage...

head_text.subj: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY

text: TEAGUE'S MEN RIDE UP TO THE FARM. Esco's out in the field labouring away, but with his shotgun by him. Teague stops alongside the field, the rail between him and Esco. Esco  stops working, picks up his shotgun and goes over. Teague has four men with him. MO and JO, the twins, huge, and wi the appearance of having less than one brain between the of them, GRAYLING, a reluctant-looking man, funereal in h bearing, and BOSIE.
Afternoon.
The riders slowly fan out, almost as if choreographed.
Don't spread out. Why they spreading  out?
I'm not spreading out. I'm sitting  here.
Esco comes over the rail fence, his gun loose in his hand
Never knew a man worked in his field  with a shotgun.
There's a war on.
Got to watch out for the Bogey Man.
He starts to fish out a tobacco pouch. Esco's gun swings Teague shows him the leather pouch, shrugs, starts to mak cigarette.

head_text.subj: INT. SWANGER FARM. DAY

text: From inside the house, Sally watches everything. Her view impaired by the sheets.

head_text.subj: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY

text: Mo dismounts. Ambles past Esco, looks behind the sheets.  ESCO KICKS OUT AT HIM, the shotgun rigid and pointing.
Get off my land.
Mo examines his breeches for a dust mark, wipes it off,  retreating in a turkey walk of examining and dusting.
Your boys come back.
Ain't seen my boys in four years.  They're fighting other boys, not old  men and women.
(to his men) He means us. He's referring there to  us. (to Esco) So you won't care if we take a look  around?
What I gotta give you? A chicken? A  lamb?
(shrugs) Sure.
Right then.
Thing is -- you got one barrel and  there's five of us. Not a fair fight.

head_text.subj: BOSIE SUDDENLY DROPS OFF HIS HORSE, ROLLS ON THE GROUND.

text: Bogey Man! Bogey Man!
Esco is momentarily distracted and, in that instant, Mo k out at him, knocking the gun from his hands, which fires  into the air, a shocking sound.

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ruby and Ada digging a trench by the smokehouse, laying i the pale heads of cabbage. They hear the distant shot.
What's that?
They stop. Listen. Look at each other, start running.

head_text.subj: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY

text: Jo sets on Esco, knocking him-backwards into a sheet, whe it gets twisted, while Jo kicks and punches, little spots blood staining the sheet with each blow. MO PULLS OUT HIS

head_text.subj: SABRE AND RUNS ESCO THROUGH, LEAVES THE SABRE IN DEEP, PI
ESCO TO THE SHEET, THEN SPINNING HIM ROUND IN THE SHEET S

text: THAT IT TIGHTENS. A stain grows out from the blade, huge spreading. Teague walks to Esco.

You're harbouring deserters. I can  confiscate every animal on this farm,  every plate, every sheet, every little  pellet of chicken shit -- I can  confiscate your old lady's asshole,  so don't offer me a bird.
Sally runs out, screaming. She tries to pull out the sabr MO REVERSES HIS RIFLE AND CLUBS HER TO THE GROUND.
(sharply) Hey!
Mo backs away. Sally is screaming. She watches, helpless, Esco dies in front of her, the sheet growing a darker red
You got your bait. Set it on the  hook.

head_text.subj: BOSIE, SMILING, FETCHES A ROPE FROM HIS HORSE, ALREADY NO
AT ONE END. HE FLIPS THE LOOP OVER SALLY'S HEAD.
INT. BARN, SWANGER FARM. DAY

text: ELLIS AND ACTON SWANGER emerge from their hiding places,  unable to bear the sound of their mother's screams. They' carrying an axe, a pitchfork, mad for revenge.

head_text.subj: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY
BOSIE IS DOING SOME SORT OF DANCE ALONG THE FENCE RAIL. H

text: very graceful, his hair flying, his hands out, one finger nail extremely long, his boots stamping down on the fence

head_text.subj: UNDER HIS STOMPING FEET, THE RAIL POST IS PRESSED ON SALL

text: SWANGER'S THUMBS. She can't scream any longer, because th noose has practically strangled her. The rope's tied off Bosie's horse, which yanks on the noose with every slight movement. Sally is prostrate in the dirt. Her two boys come running from the barn. TEAGUE CASUALLY,

head_text.subj: SHOOTS ELLIS WITH HIS RIFLE. BOSIE LETS ACTON GET ALL THE
WAY TOWARDS HIM AND THEN SHOOTS HIM FROM A YARD AWAY, THE
GUN SUDDENLY SPRINGING INTO HIS HAND. AS ACTON FALLS, BOS
DOES A FLIP TO DIVE OFF THE POST AND LAND ON HIS FEET NEX
TO ACTON'S BODY.
EXT. SWANGER FARM. DUSK

text: Ada and Ruby, riding together on the horse, arrive at the Swangers. SALLY IS STILL PINNED UNDER THE FENCE POST. The noose aro her neck has been tied off to the post so that she can't  move. There's a bloody sheet draped over the edge of the  well. Blood on the ground. Ruby heaves at the fence.
I can't get this damn thing off her.
(at the well, looking  down) Dear Lord in heaven.
Ada, I can't get this off her!
Ada runs over. They struggle, can't lift it. Sally's lips are moving.
What darling? What?
She bends down, listens to her. Looks up at Ada.
She's saying don't bother.
Wait!

She grabs a thick log off the stack, staggers back and in second they've inserted it into the fence and levered it and away from Sally's hands. They fall back onto the dirt Ruby cradles Sally. Ada nods towards the well.
There's someone down there. I think  it's Esco.
Ruby looks over at the well, then at Ada.
This world won't stand long. God  won't let it stand this way long.

head_text.subj: INT. MADDY'S CARAVAN. DAY

text: An exotic interior, many crocks and jars, bunches of herb wrapped papers of dried things, like a woodland apothecar store. Inman wakes up. He finds himself in a small cot,  wrapped in blankets, a poultice at his neck. He doesn't k where he is or how long he's been there.

head_text.subj: EXT. MADDY'S CARAVAN. DAY

text: Maddy's sitting on a stool. There's a circle of stones wh her fire lives and she sets the tinder to it. Inman emerg from the caravan. He's pale and unsteady.
How long have I been sleeping?
Not long enough.
I can't stop here. I'm a deserter.  They find me here things could be  bad for you.
What they going to do? Cut short my  young life? Sit down before you fall  down.
She calls over a little goat. It ambles over affectionate and nuzzles into her hand. She strokes it and scratches u the chin. The creature gets increasingly tranquil.
How long you been up here?
What year are we? '63?
Last time I checked it was '64.
I'd say twenty six years.
Twenty six years!
I could move on anytime. I've seen  most of the world anyway, Richmond  in the North, south almost to  Charleston. You're going somewhere  or you are somewhere, what's the  difference?
She's still stroking the goat. It looks as if it's asleep
I've learned a person can survive  off pretty much of a goat. I can't  abide a chicken, but a goat gives  you company and milk and cheese and  then, when you need it, good meat.

In a single motion she has a knife in her hand and has SL THE THROAT OF THE GOAT, putting the bowl underneath its n to catch the blood, still stroking the goat, which blinks if it were only surprised and not dying.
So you've been fighting?
(as if he might break) I could be at killing for days  sometimes, in the hand to hand, my  feet against the feet of my enemy  and I always killed him and he never  killed me.
He gave it a try, to look at you.
I guess he did.
See I think there's a plan. There's  a design. For each and every one of  us.
During this she's shucked the skin off the goat with the  authority of someone who's done this a thousand times.
You look at nature, a bird flies  somewhere, picks up a seed, shits  the seed out, a plant grows. Bird's  got a job, seed's got a job.
And the goat is now thin and pink, eyes bulging, a piece meat.

head_text.subj: INT. MADDY'S CARAVAN. EVENING

text: A woodburning stove with a single cooking plate -- on whi pieces of the goat meat, sprinkled with herbs, are sizzli in a pan.

head_text.subj: INMAN IS EATING LIKE A MAN POSSESSED, WRAPPING THE MEAT I

text: CORN FRITTERS AND PUSHING THEM INTO HIS MOUTH. Maddy watc him, adds another mound of meat to his plate. Inman nods thanks, but -- doesn't look up. She opens a jar and takes out a handful of dried poppy he puts them near the stove, then dips into another jar and  pulls out what look like old cheroot stubs.
Take one of these now with your food.
Inman is circumspect, views the stub lozenge with suspici
Swallow it. If you die I'll give you  your money back.
Inman puts it in his mouth, gags at the taste of it. She  hands him a beaker with milk to wash it down.
Our minds aren't made to hold on to  the particulars of pain, the way we  do bliss.
She starts steaming the poppies.
It's true...
What is?
What you remember.
What's her name?
Ada. (At the food) -- Sometimes I think I'm crazy when  I'm just hungry -- (another mouthful) Ada Monroe.
And is she waiting for you?
She was. I don't know. Or if she'd  know me. I'm like the boy who goes  out in winter for firewood comes  back in the spring with a whistle.
Maddy pricks open the poppies and collects their opium, t hands Inman the liquid.
Now drink this. It visits the pain.  And you'll sleep.
He drinks the laudanum she's made.
I've had to put myself in the way of  people's kindness.
I hope you found it.

She dips a cloth in the steaming water, unbuttons his shi She has a crock of what looks like treacle and vaseline. smears this salve over the neck wound and into his scalp. Inman surrenders to the drug.
The passenger pigeons fly south, the  berries ripen. Whether I see them or  not, whether a man dies, or a war is  won.
That's the laudanum getting to you.  That's good. Say something more. (she kneels to his  leg) Raise that up for me.
He obliges. She grimaces at the state of it, where the ch has chewed into the flesh. Gets to work.

She gave me a book. Ada Monroe. Man  by the name of Bartram. Wrote about  his travels. I carried that book  through every battle. I left it  someplace, got to get it back.  Sometimes just reading the name of a  place near home -- Sorell Cove, Fire  Scale Ridge -- was enough to bring  me to tears. Thing is I've been  thinking -- those places belonged to  people before us, to the Indian --  and he had a different name. What  did he call Sorell Cove? How can a  name not even the real name break  your heart? It's her, she's the place  I'm heading. And I hardly know her.  So how can a person who's maybe not  even a real person -- I don't know  what I'm talking about -- I have to  close my eyes...
He slides off the stool and lays on the floor. Maddy goes over to her cot and pulls off a blanket which she drapes  over him.

head_text.subj: EXT. YARD, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ada in the henhouse, collecting eggs, is confident now am the birds. She emerges to find Ruby walking out of the  backdoor with the shotgun and a determined look.
It's a man.
What is?
Raiding our corn. Got him in the  trap. That's him yelping.
You're not going to shoot him!
I don't want him to shoot me. (of the gun) Can you fire this thing?
(making it clear she  can't) Yes.

They head towards the corn crib, bundled up against the c A MAN IS KNEELING AT THE CORN CRIB, perfectly caught in t art of stealing, his head forced away from view. Ruby han Ada the gun and approaches, warily.
Listen up -- you got a barrel trained  on your rear-end.
Get me out of this dang thing. My  fist's about to drop off.
You got a weapon?
No ma'am. I'm begging you. I'm already  on my knees, otherwise I'd get down  on them.
(suddenly recognises  the voice) Unbelievable! Stobrod Thewes.
Ruby? God damn!
What?
(to Ada, disgusted) That's my daddy...
She walks up to him and KICKS HIM HARD AS SHE CAN ON HIS  BACKSIDE.

head_text.subj: INT. KITCHEN, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: A strip of fabric, homemade bandage, being wrapped around Stobrod's badly gashed hand. Ada is tending to him. Ruby cooking at the range, not remotely warm towards her prodi father, who looks rather comfortable. Stobrod looks at he
Just so's you know -- I can eat while  she's doing this -- in case you're  holding off.
Just so's you know -- you're not  eating inside. Number One -- they  hang people round here for taking in  deserters. Number two -- even if  they gave out prizes -- you'd still  eat outside.

I hurt you.
Good God!

Fair enough.

head_text.subj: INT. SARA'S CABIN. NIGHT

text: Inman enters the cabin. It's a single room. A big fire. T baby on the bed, a rudimentary crib unoccupied next to it The woman is already at the little stove. She turns to hi She's painfully beautiful. But sad and fragile. Inman, de himself, is mesmerized.
Thank you.
I'm alone here, as you can see, with  my baby. I need to believe you mean  no harm.
Inman takes out his gun. She starts, terrified.
No, I mean to give it to you.
He turns it handle forwards and offers it to her.

He cries. I don't know. He cries a  lot. My man is dead. He took his  wound at Fredericksburg. Never saw  his boy.

I'm sorry.

She hands him a plate of steaming beans. An onion perched top.
It's mean food but it's hot.

She goes over to the bed and picks up her baby and starts the same business of walking him, singing the while, an o lament. Inman eats, looks at her, at the child and the fi He picks up the onion, bites into it. Sara looks across.
(ashamed of his hunger) There's no hunting on the road, just  cress and --
He takes another bite. Sara picks up the baby.

Used to have a cow, few goats. Raiders  took them. Made me kill our own dog  on the porch. That poor creature  watched over me. Glad to know you both.

I got a blanket.

head_text.subj: INT. SARA'S CABIN. NIGHT

Good night.

text: Inman comes in. Sara is sitting on her bed. Long silence.
Could you do something for me? Do  you think you could lie here, next  to me, and not need to go further?
I don't know. I'll try.

He sits on the bed as she slips under the covers, and the removes the boots, his shirt, gets under the covers. Ther an electric space between them. Then Sara begins to cry,  pulls his arm to open up so that she can be folded into h SHE SOBS, SHUDDERING IN THE BED.

head_text.subj: INT. OLD MILL, COLD MOUNTAIN. CHRISTMAS DAY. NIGHT

text: THE MUSIC CONTINUES. Stobrod is playing the fiddle, his b hand still lightly taped and a fingerless mitten covering it. (of Sally) She don't speak.
She can't speak. I told you.
(smiles at Sally) Is she feeble then?
No. (to Sally) Don't mind him. (to Ruby) Hey Ruby: what about this?
He starts the tune of Wayfaring Stranger. Ruby groans.
Don't make that face -- you listen:  c'mon Georgia...

And he starts up again, but this time GEORGIA BEGINS TO S He's like a pale angel and sings with a soft, true voice. Ruby sits next to Ada, fiddles with her bracelet slips one from Ada's wrist and slides it over her own.

head_text.subj: EXT. OLD MILL, COLD MOUNTAIN. EVENING

text: They're all outside now, shaking hands.
There's snow in the air.
Don't sleep here.
We won't.
It's bitter, they could stop one  night.
They stop one night, they'll want to  stop two.
This coat's warm.
What about next Sunday? That'll be  the New Year. It's gonna be a better  one.
Maybe.
The war's over in a month.
He said that a month ago.
(shaking Stobrod's  hand in goodnight) It started off being over in a month.
Miss Ada. Merry Christmas.
Merry Christmas. Pangle. Georgia.
'Night.
'Night now.
The three women walk down the lane, the three men watch.
That's my Ruby.
She's an original.
You think the Good Lord would forgive  an old cold fool if he changed his  mind? Ada said it herself it was  bitter...

head_text.subj: EXT. SWANGER FARM. NIGHT

text: The three women head towards Sally's house.
What kind of name's Georgia?
It's where he comes from, it's not  his name.
I know that's meant to be the ugliest  state under the heavens.
Why do you care what his name is?
(a funny look, then) What's that cluster of Stars?
Orion.
What about them shaped like a  wishbone?
That's Taurus the bull, and that's  Gemini and that's Orion's big dog,  Canis Major.
Listen to her, Sal. She's turned  into a highland girl.
I could always name the stars, Ruby,  that was never my problem.
They all three have linked arms. Ada imitates Stobrod.
I love you darling. In case that big  old sky falls on our heads. And I  love you, too. Sal.
It's sad, Sal. It's a c-a-t-a-s-t-r- o-p-h-e.

head_text.subj: INT. ADA'S BEDROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. MORNING

text: Ada at the window as, outside, SNOW FLAKES BEGIN TO FALL.

text: Stobrod opens the door of the Mill. The SNOW FLAKES dissu him from venturing further. He goes back inside.
No sense setting off in snow.

head_text.subj: THE DOOR SHUTS, FIDDLE MUSIC LEAKS THROUGH THE DOOR, FOLL
BY BANJO AND HARMONICA.

text: Sara, dressed, agitated -- the baby already complaining - is urgently shaking Inman. Hissing at him:
Get out of here, quick!
Inman surfaces from deep sleep.
Federals are coming. They find you  here it'll go bad on all of us.
Inman is up, grabbing clothes, boots, his gun.
I can try and fight them.
No, my baby. Please no! Just get.
She pulls up the window in back of the cabin. Inman throw things out into the freezing morning. He has his pants on but is otherwise naked. He swings over the window and dow onto the frosty ground.

Inman picks up his stuff and, at a crouch, runs for cover the wood which borders the property. He can hear horses a a commotion at the front of Sara's cabin, but doesn't loo round until he's sheltered by the trees. FEDERAL SOLDIERS, a raiding party, have dismounted and ar already wrangling with Sara. Inman watches, pulling on hi shirt, shivering, then his boots. Sara is standing in front of the hogpen, as if to protect the animal, but one of the soldiers, PISTOL, barges her t one side, toppling her, and opens the gate, starts herdin the hog out into the yard. A second soldier, NYM, emerges from the cabin, carrying Ethan. Sara starts up, struggles with him, is again knocked down.

head_text.subj: INMAN HAS TO WATCH AS THEY DRAG HER OVER TO A FENCE POST
ROPE HER TO IT THEN SLIP THE BLANKET OFF THE BABY AND LAY
ON THE GROUND IN THE MIDDLE OF THE YARD.

We got all day.
My baby's sick! Cover him up! He's  shaking! Have some pity.
A third Federal, BARDOLPH, chases after the chickens, gat them up.
I got nothing. I swear.
Nym gets close to her, putting his rifle to her chest.
That ain't necessarily so.
Yes! Take me inside! Let's all go  inside! Take my baby inside and then  we'll do whatever you want.
Nym unties her. Pistol has a rope around the hog and now  leads it towards the horses.
(screaming) There's nothing! You take that hog  I'm as good as dead. Cover up my  boy!

head_text.subj: INT. SARA'S CABIN. DAY

text: The door is kicked open. Nym pushes Sara inside, kicks th door shut, REVEALING INMAN STANDING BEHIND IT.

head_text.subj: EXT. SARA'S CABIN. DAY

text: Bardolph, a chicken in his arms, goes over to the baby.
This is ready to get a fit going.  It's shuddering. It's gone blue.
(to Nym) How long does he want? Hey! Leave  some for the rest of us.

Pistol laughs, ent and is clubbed down by Inman, who steps out onto the porc while SARA SHRUGS OFF THE BODY OF NYM, HIS THROAT CUT. Bardolph looks up to see Inman walking towards him. Bardo has left his weapon by the fence.
Move away from the baby.

Don't shoot.
Take off your boots. (Bardolph does so) Take off your pants, and your shirt.

head_text.subj: EXT. CABBAGE PATCH, BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK

(shrugs) This snow. Isn't it supposed to fall  with bad news?

head_text.subj: EXT. OLD MILL, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY

head_text.subj: EXT. SLOPES OF COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY

text: Pangle walks too close to Stobrod and steps on the back o his boot which promptly detaches itself from Stobrod's fo Stobrod turns -- and with a raised finger -- pushes Pangl PANGLE FALLS IN THE SNOW, ARMS SPREADEAGLED, AND SMILES.

head_text.subj: EXT. PIGEON RIVER BEHIND THE OLD MILL. DAY
