Mr. Teague wants us to play.
Okay.
We heard there were deserters in  these parts. Hiding out in a big  cave.
Not come to my ears.
You don't know where this cave is?
No, sir.
You do, Stobes! He means --
Right, right! he means, there is a  cave, right, it's up over the other  side, big cave, we played some music  up there, never occurred to me they  were deserters. Near Bearpen Branch.

Ain't nowhere near Bearpen Branch!  It's this side! He's always getting  lost. That cave -- we live there! --  it's over on Big Stomp. Tell you how  I always find it. There's a big old  locust tree fell down across the  path, that points straight at it,  like a finger, always a dozen  squirrels round that tree. You gets  to the tree, sit on it, and there's  your entrance, straight in front of  you, tree points at it. Come right  to your hand, them squirrels -- (makes a chirping  sound) -- Chrrrpppp! Chrrrrppp!
Sounds good. Okay, let's eat, let's  hear some music.

head_text.subj: EXT. TREES NEAR KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT

text: Georgia watches as the music starts, Stobrod playing and  singing, Pangle joining in at the chorus. Their improvisi is wild, profound, Stobrod chording the fiddle, Pangle  following him, then, finishing with another verse and end with the title declaimed by Stobrod.
I call this tune: Ruby's Lament.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT

text: Something like compassion has flickered over Teague's fac Mo and Jo nod to the music's secret rhythms. Only Bosie s detached, contemplating his long fingernail. The music  finishes. The Home Guard applaud.
What'd you make of that?
Heartbreaking.
Stand over by that tree.
Me?
Over by that tree. Over there. Take  your boyfriend.
Stobrod gets up, carrying his fiddle, heads over to a big old poplar. Nods at Pangle.
Come on.
Pangle gets up, banjo in his hand. Puts his arm around St as if they were about to be photographed. The Home Guard  gather around them. From the trees Georgia watches, helpl Pangle grins at Teague.
Don't smile.
What?
Quit smiling.
He always smiles. He don't mean  nothing by it. I told him this world's  got nothing worth a smile.
Put your hat over your face.
What do you mean?
Cover your face with your hat.

head_text.subj: HE OBLIGIES, TEAGUE'S CARBINE SPRINGS UP IN HIS HAND AND
EXT. TREES NEAR THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT

text: Georgia lies prostrate in the snow, shuddering under the  report of each bullet.

head_text.subj: EXT. BOTTOM FIELD, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ruby working in the snow, in the field, clipping a sheep' feet, the animal on its back between Ruby's knees. She lo up to see GEORGIA RUNNING ACROSS THE FIELD TOWARDS HER,  calling out her name. From the kitchen window, Ada looks as he reaches Ruby, the story pouring from him. Ada emerg from the house, walks towards the bad news.

head_text.subj: INT. STOREROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: Ruby sorting out a kit of shovels, blankets. Ada comes in doesn't know how to help her friend, who shows no emotion
I told Georgia he can stop here,  sleep in the barn. He's got nothing  inside him. He'd walk out of here  and die in the snow.
He can milk the cows. I was worrying  about that. It'll be dark in a couple  of hours. I's ten hours climb from  here. He's drawn a map.
Okay.

(boiling) You know these fools stayed the night  in the Mill? That's Stobrod -- he  can't do one good thing without adding  the bad. Left tracks in the snow all  the way up for them Home Guards to  follow. That's a sign says shoot me!
Ruby, I'm so sorry.
Ada moves towards her, puts her arms around her. Ruby is  rigid. Ada stops embracing her.
We should get going.
She's tying up the kit. She doesn't know how to grieve.

Every piece of this is a man's  bullshit. They call this a war a  cloud over the land, but they made  the weather. Then they stand in the  rain and say: shit! It's raining! (tears welling) If I cry one tear for my Daddy I  stole it off a crocodile.

head_text.subj: EXT. COLD MOUNTAIN. EVENING
THE SNOW IS FALLING HEAVILY. RUBY AND ADA TRUDGE UP THE

text: MOUNTAIN, dressed in Monroe's clothes, hats pulled down,  leading the horse, which is loaded up with tools and supp A choice of paths. They start up one, then Ruby decides  against it, consults the map, and they reverse, pulling t horse back and then yanking it up the other path.

head_text.subj: EXT. PI STRUCTURE, COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT

text: Ruby and Ada have made a fire. They sleep under a stone  structure, which forms a natural pi shape, the fire in th entrance, the snow caught in its light.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. MORNING

text: Ada and Ruby arrive at the scene of murder. Pangle is keeled over at the old Poplar, snow covering hi Only his girth and a glimpse of coat identify him. Ada brushes some of the snow from his face, revealing the death wound, then lays a hand in blessing on his head.
I don't understand.

Maybe Teague's took him. They did  that with the Swanger boys -- didn't,  they? -- dragged them into town,  then strung them up as warning...  it's snowed since, so I can't read  the story on the ground.
Ada fishes out Pangle's banjo from the snow. It's broken the strings hang slack.
Let's dig.

LATER -- and RUBY FINISHES OFF THE GRAVE, hammering in a  stone to mark the place. Ada walks away towards the creek to wash her hands. She bends and rinses her face. As she looks up SHE SEES STOBROD ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE CREEK; half-in, half out of the water, slumped against a  tree, blood everywhere, staining the crust of snow which  covers him.
Ruby! Ruby!

Ruby arrives at Ada, looks to where she's looking, walks  straight into the creek, all her love contained in the ur with which she hurtles to her father, oblivious to the  freezing water. She puts a head to his chest, seeks out a pulse at his wrist. Calls back to Ada.
He's still breathing! (to Stobrod) God damn! Daddy; Daddy -- it's Ruby.  Don't you die on me again. (to Ada) He's still breathing!

head_text.subj: EXT. THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. AFTERNOON

text: A mean fire burns by the creek. RUBY TURNS A KNIFE IN THE FLAMES. Stobrod's back is exposed. Just by the shoulder b is an ugly grey and purple bulge the size of a crabapple. Ruby turns to Ada, who is helping.
Pack a pan full of snow. I need good  clean water, boiled up.
She cuts the skin and prises out a slug which she drops i the snow and rolls around to clean. Stobrod doesn't move. could be dead. Ada loads the pan with snow.
Let's get him home. We have herbs  there and it's warm.
He'll die first. He's got hardly no  blood left in him.
He'll die lying here.
There's a place further on up. Used  to be. Old Cherokee place. There's  good water right by it.
Ada puts the snow-packed pan on the fire.

head_text.subj: EXT. BY THE OUTLIER'S CAVE, COLD MOUNTAIN. AFTERNOON

text: Squirrels frolic. Teague sits on the trunk of a fallen tr He feeds the squirrels, looking straight ahead where the  mouth of a cave winks back at him.

head_text.subj: EXT. TREE TUNNEL NEAR CHEROKEE VILLAGE. AFTERNOON
THE TWO WOMEN EMERGE FROM A STEEP TUNNEL OF TREES IN A

text: CHESTNUT GROVE. There's a stream and, up on the bank, A  CLUSTER OF BLACK CONICAL HUTS, made up of chestnut logs,  abandoned and slightly sinister looking. They approach on of the huts, its door long lost. The snow has drifted in. second hut has a door which they pry open. It's dark and  cold, but apparently still weatherproof. They get Stobrod off the horse and carry him inside, then come out again t unload the horse of its remaining load.
This horse is weary. He's ready to  give up the ghost.
Ruby picks up the blankets and provisions and goes back i to her father. Ada takes the horse to another hut and, de his great reluctance, pushes him inside.
Good boy. (she blows into his  nostrils, calming  him) That's warmer, isn't it.
Ada wouldn't even recognize this practical, hardy woman s become. Stringy and of few words. She sets off towards th tree tunnel, passing Stobrod's hut.
I'm getting firewood.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. DUSK

text: Inman approaches the Killing Ground. He studies the groun finds Pangle's grave. Blood has left its black writing in the snow and he finds first where Stobrod has been, where the bullet had been removed, then the journey away, still tiny, telltale spatters of blood, and the hoof prints and boot prints of two walkers and one loaded horse. He puts hand into the ashes of Ruby's fire, can't feel any warmth It's getting dark. He takes a drink from the stream, shud at the cold.

head_text.subj: INT. STOBROD'S HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. NIGHT

text: The fire burns, a pall of smoke. Stobrod lies on the grou swathed in blankets. Coughs. Ruby sits next to him, wipes the hair from his forehead. Ada opens her eyes, looks, cl them, listens to the fire, a strange squeaking as it burn
That wood -- that sound when it burns  that mean more snow?
Yes, it do, country girl.

head_text.subj: EXT. TRACK, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAWN

text: First light. The sun creeps up, a red streak of dawn. Inm walking, his head bent to the tracks. He walks quickly, e as the terrain gets more steep. As he bends to the snow - where a spot of blood has fallen into a hoof print -- A F OF SNOW LANDS ON HIS HAND. Then a second. He looks up. Th snow falls. He starts to move more quickly, racing the snow as it see to erase the tracks. The snow thickens.

head_text.subj: EXT. TREE TUNNEL NEAR CHEROKEE VILLAGE. MORNING

text: In the Chestnut Grovel A DOZEN WILD TURKEYS pick their wa across the snow. A shotgun lines up its sight at one of t The trigger is squeezed. An explosion of feathers.

head_text.subj: EXT. THREE WAY CROSSING, COLD MOUNTAIN. MORNING

text: Inman hears the shot. Then a second, the sound ricochetin around him. He can't quite identify its source but he run again, heading for the Chestnut trees he can see above hi

head_text.subj: EXT. TREE TUNNEL NEAR CHEROKEE VILLAGE. MORNING

text: Ada collects the two turkeys, the first creatures she's e shot. Doesn't quite know how to hold them. She straighten up and sees, at the other end of the tree tunnel, backlit the morning sun, THE SILHOUETTE OF A MAN. She drops the  turkeys tires to reload the shotgun. Inman comes down the tunnel, approaching the hunter he se through the snow at the other end of it.
Turn round and go back where you  came from.
Inman is bewildered by this woman's voice in a man's outf keeps walking, peering through the snow. Ada fires a warn shot. Inman, still some distance, suddenly understands.
Ada? Ada Monroe?
I do not know you.
After all this time, all this way, Inman could give up th ghost.
Then I believe I made a mistake.
He turns, walks heavily away from her. Then he turns agai completely lost, without compass.
If I knew where to go I'd go there.
(finally recognising  him) Inman?
He nods. They don't know how to speak to each other, just stand awkwardly, some distance apart, the emotion stones their throats. Eventually --
You'd better come with me.
And with that, she starts to sob, and sob. VERY HIGH ANGLE: Inman walks towards Ada. They embrace.

head_text.subj: INT. STOBROD'S HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. MORNING

text: Ada enters, Inman behind her. Ruby looks up from Stobrod.
Ruby, this is Inman.
Ruby digests this. Considers this ghost of a man.
Congratulations, I should send you  out with a shotgun more often. He  looks as he needs sleep.
I may need to.
Be my guest. You shot or something?
Not lately.
Hungry? (Inman nods, Ruby to  Ada) He woke up.
Stobrod?
Said -- your mommy's name was Grace  then closed his eyes again.

head_text.subj: EXT. CHEROKEE VILLAGE. DAY

text: Ada comes out of Stobrod's hut, a glimpse of Inman sleepi on the floor, heads for another hut which Ruby is sweepin out. The snow has stopped. Ada stands in the door, watche Ruby. Ruby's resistance to Inman is palpable.
He's asleep. They both are.
I'm not surprised. Your man looks  played out.
I saw him. I realize now.
Saw him when?
In Sally Swanger's well. A tunnel of  trees. The man like a black smudge  in the snow, the sun behind him.
Well there you are.
Funny thing is it wasn't the same.  The image. It wasn't snowing. And in  the well, he was, as if he were  falling.
You probably don't remember it right.

I remember it exactly. There were  crows, these black crows flying  towards me. I thought I was seeing  him fall. Instead I was seeing him  come back to me. All this while I've  been packing ice around my heart.  How will I make it melt?
Better get a fire going. (goes to the fireplace) I've got big plans for that farm.  Got a vision in my mind of how that  Cove needs to be.
I know you have.
There's not a thing we can't do  ourselves.

head_text.subj: INT. ADA AND RUBY HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. NIGHT

text: THE FIRE BURNS. Ada lies awake. Ruby sleeping. Ada gets u steps out into the snow, her blanket around her.

head_text.subj: EXT. ADA AND RUBY HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. NIGHT

text: Inman is outside his cabin. Only the light escaping from cabin, fire lights them, almost silhouettes.
I'm sorry. I was trying to be quiet.
I couldn't sleep.
-- I got no appetite left to be in a  room with wounded men.
I can't see your face.
It's not a face you recognised.
Did you get my letters?
I got three letters. Carried them in  that book you gave me. The Bertram.
I must have sent 100. Did you write  to me?
Whenever I could. If you never got  them I can summarize.
No, it's --
I pray you're well. I pray I'm in  your thoughts. You are all that keeps  me from sliding into some dark place.
But how did I keep you? We barely  knew each other. A few moments.

A thousand moments. They're like a  bag of tiny diamonds glittering in a  black heart. Don't matter if they're  real or things I made up. The shape  of your neck. The way you felt under  my hands when I pulled you to me.
Your boots, one polished, one not  yet polished.
You're playing a piano and I'm  standing outside.
I'm playing a piano and you're  standing outside.
That kiss -- which I've kissed again  every day of my walking.
Every day of my waiting.

Maybe you can't see my face, but if  you could see my inside, my whatever  you want to name it, my spirit, that's  the fear I have deeper than any gash  on my neck. I think I'm ruined. They  kept trying to put me in the ground,  but I wasn't ready, no ma'am, no  more ready than that scoundrel in  there's not ready to die on us. But  if I had goodness, I lost it. If I  had anything tender in me I shot it  dead.
Ruby stomps out of the hut.

Number one -- shut this door, it's  freezing. (goes over to Stobrod's  hut) Number two -- shut that door, it's  freezing. (turns to them) I'm laying on my back, with my fingers  poked in my ears trying to shut out  who's got a bag of diamonds and who's  got boots needs polishing, If you  want to get three feet up a bull's  ass listen to what sweethearts whisper  to each other.
She's at the door to Stobrod's hut. She contemplates them
In fact, if you're going to wimble  all night I'm going to sleep in with  him.
And with that she enters Stobrod's hut, slamming the door
Now I can't see anything.
A long pause.
I'll say goodnight.
I don't think Ruby's vacating my hut  so that you can sleep in a different  one.

head_text.subj: INT. ADA AND RUBY HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. NIGHT

text: Ada puts logs onto the fire. After a few moments a knock.
Come in.
Inman enters. They don't know the rules for this.
Whatever comes to pass between you  and me, I want Ruby to stay in Black  Cove.
Right.
As long as she wants. And if she  never leaves I'll be glad.
More a question could she put up  with me.
And you understand she's my friend,  she's not a hired hand and she doesn't  empty a night jar unless it's her  own.
Sure.
This war's made some things pointless.  It's hard to imagine a wedding. I  think even my father would recognize  that.
Ada, I want to marry you. If you'll  have me.
Isn't there's some religion where  you just have to say I marry you,  three times, and then you're man and  wife.
I marry you. I marry you. I marry  you.
Ada laughs, unsettling Inman.
Why's that funny?
No, I think it's I divorce you three  times and then you're not married  anymore.
I can wait for you.
You waited enough. I certainly did.  I marry you. I marry you. I marry  you.
And they kiss, tentative, then more urgent.
I'm sorry about the way I look. In  these clothes. (Inman shakes his  head) And there are so many buttons. (starts to undress) Will you turn your back?
Not for all the gold dollars in the  Federal Bank.
She stands holding her clothes in front of her to cover  herself. He takes them from her, drops them to the floor.

head_text.subj: EXT. CHEROKEE VILLAGE. MORNING

text: A crisp, cold beautiful morning. They're packing up, all  their clothes in layers. Inman prepares the horse. Ruby a Ada carrying bundles out of the huts. Inman approaches Ru
You go ahead. I'll follow with the  horse at a pace your daddy can  tolerate.
We can all go together.
It's safer this way. No one has  quarrel with you.
He's right.
(to Ruby) I gather I need permission if I reckon  on living at Black Cove.
Ruby gives a curt nod, goes over to Stobrod's hut. Inman  gets close to Ada.
We'll get to you by nightfall.
You be safe.
She puts her hand to his mouth which creases into a smile

Your Mr. Bartram speaks about some  category of fly born on the hide of  a cow. It flies up into a tree and  waits and waits until it smells cow.  It can wait a year, two years, I  don't know, maybe longer. Then a cow  comes along and it wakes up, flies  down, lays its eggs on the cow.  There's purpose for you.
And am I the fly in this story, or  the cow?

head_text.subj: INT. STOBROD'S HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. DAY

text: Ruby is wrapping a fragile Stobrod for the journey.
You come up the mountain for me,  darling, I'd be dead otherwise, dead  and gone.
You'd have found some other fool to  rescue you.
He's sweet on you, that Georgia boy.
He coughs for a long time.
If you say a thing and then cough  it's a lie. Daddy, stay on that horse,  and don't lose him or sell him. We'll  need him on the farm.

head_text.subj: EXT. CHEROKEE VILLAGE. MORNING

text: And then the two women are off, little men in their outfi tramping off in the snow. Inman watches.

head_text.subj: EXT. TRACK NEAR THREE WAY CROSSING, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY

text: Ruby and Ada walk.
I hope that Georgia boy's been seeing  to the animals.
I thought you were thinking on him!
I was not. I was thinking on swollen  udders -- and before you say same  difference...
I'm saying nothing.
Ruby elbows her.
Miss lovey-dovey!
Ada elbows her back.

head_text.subj: EXT. THREE WAY CROSSING, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY

text: Inman has roped Stobrod to the horse which he pulls down steep slope. Behind him, their hooves muffled by the snow

head_text.subj: GROUP OF RIDERS JOIN THE TRAIL, IN SLOW BUT STEADY PURSUI

text: Inman walks on, apparently oblivious to who's behind him. and Stobrod are some distance from broken ground, a fring of trees.
(quietly to Stobrod) Don't look round.
Got it.
How many men does he have?
There were five. You can't reason  with that man.
(takes off his gloves) I got a conversation stopper. (they're getting closer) Closer we get to that broken ground  the better.
Inman opens his coat. Stobrod looks at the Lemats. They'r at the edge of the trees.
You hold on tight, do you hear? When  I say three, look round, nice and  slow.
Okay.
One, two, three.
Stobrod looks round. Inman doesn't. Teague has some new b in his entourage but they're all dead. A SPARE HORSE HAS

head_text.subj: THREE CORPSES HUNG OVER IT, ANOTHER HORSE DRAGS A MAKESHI
LITTER WITH A COUPLE MORE, SOUVENIRS OF THEIR CAVE VISIT.

text: Teague waves.
God damn! You're a hard fucker to  put down. (they approach) Good directions to that cave from  the fat boy -- saw the squirrels,  sat on the tree made some friends,  brought some back with me.
His riders begin, quite casually, to fan out.

head_text.subj: IN ONE MOVEMENT, INMAN SLAPS THE FLANK OF THE HORSE. WHIC
CAREERS DOWN THE TRACK, THEN TURNS AND FIRES, TWICE, BEFO
PITCHING HIMSELF INTO A ROLL TOWARDS THE TREES. HIS FIRST
SHOT KNOCKS JO FROM HIS HORSE, THE SECOND MO, WHO FALLS I

text: THE SNOW, BLEEDING FROM THE GROIN AND SCREAMING. The ride horse gets tangled up with the others. Inman is in the trees, shots around him. He doesn't move  away from, but towards the riders inside the line of tree Grayling charges him, riding into the trees. INMAN SHOOTS

head_text.subj: HIM, THEN RUSHES FROM THE TREES, FIRING, MISSING BOSIE, W
RIDES AWAY, EVIDENTLY NOT RELISHING THE FIGHT, AND THROWS

text: HIMSELF AT TEAGUE, WHOSE HORSE IS BUCKING WILDLY. Teague' carbine fires an involuntary shot into the air. Inman yan the gun from his hand with his own left hand and lets go shotgun barrel of the Lemats with the other, the big pist almost leaping from his hand with the recoil. TEAGUE'S CH OPENS OUT AS HE'S THROWN OFF THE HORSE. Mo is still screa Inman walks over and shoots him in the head, then walks t Teague, who is saying something, the blood blotting the s under him. Inman studies him, picks up the Spencer carbine, turns to look where Bosie has gone, steps up onto Teague's horse,  reins the horse in, and trots it over to the prostrate Te LEANS OVER AND SHOOTS HIM DEAD. He turns the horse in the direction Bosie had headed. He can't see horse or rider, in the stand of Hickory Trees ahead, THE GUSTS OF STEAMIN BREATH betray them both. He rides slowly towards the stan of trees.

head_text.subj: EXT. COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY

text: Ada and Ruby walking. They hear the shots. Ada turns and  starts to run through the snow, her hat flying from her h

head_text.subj: EXT. STAND OF HICKORY TREES, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY

text: Inman's horse is parallel to Bosie, who is deep inside th trees but also riding, slowly. It's like a dance.
Come out of there.
No, sir. Here's fine.
I just have to shoot the horse from  under you.
Shoot her. She's not mine. You riding  Mr Teague's mare?
I am.
He dead?
I hope so. (wearily, as he brings  his horse inside the  trees) Look, how old are you? Give me your  gun and ride home, I'm done fighting.  I'm sick of it.
I give you my gun you'll shoot me  dead.
I will not shoot you, but nor am I  walking down that mountain looking  over my shoulder for you.
That's what they call a conundrum. I  tell you what I've got on my side.
What have you got on your side?
The confidence of youth.
And in that second HE PRODUCES HIS GUN AND FIRES. INMAN H

head_text.subj: THE HEAD, F
CAUGHT BY ONE STIRRUP THE HORSE BOLTING. INMAN WATCHES, S
STILL, THEN MAKES A COUGH, AS IF CLEARING HIS THROAT, AND
THIN MIST OF BLOOD SPRAYS FROM HIS MOUTH.
EXT. RIDGE, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY

text: Ada and Ruby running. THEY REACH STOBROD, HIS HORSE STOPP DRINKING FROM THE CREEK. Stobrod, barely conscious, hangi halfway down its flank, held on by the ropes. Ada hurries on, taking the shotgun from Ruby, who tends t her father.

head_text.subj: EXT. A GROVE OF TREES, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY

text: Ada runs past the horse dragging the cave corpses. She ha stops to look at the bodies, just rushes on. THE GROUND SIMPLIFIES AND SHE'S AT THE BOTTOM OF A GROVE.

head_text.subj: STEEP INCLINE, THE SUN LOW AND IN FRONT OF HER. SHE SEES
BRILLIANT FRAME OF BLACK TREES, AND THEN A SUDDEN FLURRY
ANGRY CROWS FLYING TOWARDS HER. AT THE TOP OF THE HILL IS
SMALL HIEROGLYPH OF A MAN.
FINALLY, THE IMAGE FROM THE SWANGER WELL EXACTLY AS SHE F
SAW IT.
THE FIGURE RAISES A HAND, BRIEFLY, THEN PITCHES FORWARD I
THE SNOW.

text: She runs, her heart broken, towards the body of Inman. He dead, the red flag of his life ebbed, away in the snow. A falls to her knees and pulls him over, the snow crusted o his face, which she wipes away with great tenderness, the sits, his head in her lap, as Ruby slowly comes up the hi towards them. A VIOLIN PLAYS, quite raucous.

head_text.subj: INT. KITCHEN, BLACK COVE FARM, EASTER. DAY

text: A GIRL, about five or six, with Ada's curls, sits at the  table cradling a tiny lamb, which won't feed from the nip bottle she offers it. She tries again. Ada comes in sudde takes a knife from the kitchen, and hurries out.
You bring that lamb outside.
The girl gets up, carries the lamb out into the field.

head_text.subj: EXT. FIELD, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: THE SOUND OF THE FIDDLE CONTINUING, JOINED BY A BANJO, It a glorious spring morning, Black Cove Farm at its most  luxuriant, the path edged with brilliant flowers. There a more animals in evidence. The girl emerges from the house and sees Ada in the field, surrounded by sheep. She hurri over. ADA IS EXPERTLY SKINNING A STILLBORN LAMB. The little gir is horrified.
What are you doing!
He came out dead, love.
She has the skin off the lamb, which lies like a little p cat on the ground. She approaches Grace, takes the live l from her arms, the girl resistant, frightened.
Don't kill him!
I'm not going to kill him. But we  have to try something or else he's  going to die.

She takes the skin and wraps it round Grace's lamb. Then  puts the covered lamb into the pen with the dead lamb's  mother. It goes to the sheep and, after a few false starts, start to feed, accepted as a surrogate.
Isn't that a small mercy.
And A VOICE joins in with the fiddle and banjo.

head_text.subj: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DAY

text: STOBROD is playing, on his repaired fiddle. His hair is n completely grey. GEORGIA is playing the banjo and singing although. A SMALL CHILD with Georgia's reddish coloring k invading his picking hand trying to join in. RUBY HAS ANO GEORGIA CHILD IN HER ARMS, but is also trying to serve fo She passes Georgia and touches the top of his head. SALLY SWANGER is pouring water from a jug, Ada emerges from the kitchen, with a big pie, racing to the table.
(laughing) Hot hot hot hot hot!!!
From behind her, Grace appears, carrying a jug of milk, p it on the groaning board of the table. Grace has a full p in front of her, picks up a fork to spear some meat.
Grace Inman, nobody said eat. (then to Stobrod) Mr. Thewes...
The music stops. And there's quiet except for the sound o animals: lowing, barking, braying, bleating.
For good friends, good food, good  family: for all our blessings -- Oh  Lord we thank thee. Amen.
Amen !
And they eat.
